Blog.post: today's post is dedicated to Jon Marcus--- and the ever expanding debate over objective morality we've been having. I claim that the attempt to prove that objective truth does not exist ends in contradiction because to state that objective truth doesn't exist itself is a contradiction--- in other words Jon is trying to say that it is objectively true that there is no such thing as objective truth. Jon insists ("congratulations sir," he says in that silly debate voice) that the disproof of the opposite of something doesn't prove its existence. . . this seems silly to me, first year logic teaches you that (x---> a and ~a, therefore ~x) Doesn't Helen teach you anything, Jon? but more importantly, that's not really the point-- its not that you cant disprove objective truth that makes objective truth inevitable-- its that you can't utter any intelligable reasons for it. For example, Jon claims by my own logic, you can't disprove that there is an invisible, intangible rabbit sitting on his head, therefore it must be there. no Jon, its not the same thing. I can give you arguments why the rabbit isn't there, arguments like, I can't see it, there's no evidence its there, etc. . . arguments which can be proven true or false, either empirically or logically. the difference is that to provide reasons why there is no objective truth is to not say anything at all, in the sense that contradictions are meaningless. we can later argue what those truths may, in fact be, and i don't claim that human beings know or even can know all of them-- although i do believe they are all self-evidently true, this is an epistomalogical debate-- whether we can know them, not a metaphysical debate-- whether they exist at all. By the same token of your own arguments, Jon, you claim that all truths are socially constructed. that truth, itself, must then be socially contstructed, and so there may be some societies which hold their own truths to be true for everyone. . . and since you deny, and must deny, the ability of any society to be able to judge the morals of other societies as true or false, you must deny your own ability to deny the truths of that one objective truth society. and since you cannot object to it, you must accept it--- you must say then, "it is true for that society that truth is true for everyone" and so you make yourself accountable to that society's truths, disobeying them or denying them denies your own claim that truth is socially constructed. I, however, would be able to say that society has correct or incorrect beliefs about truth; I can analyize their tennents in a way you cannot. suppose that society claims that it is objectivly true, that is true for everyone, that it is morally good to enslave black people. ( I know i'm setting up a straw man here, but the process by which i'm going to argue can serve to prove my point, not the actual argument) You are not able to say that that is an immoral society, it is truly their belief that black people are immoral. But wait there's more. By not yourself enslaving black people, you are dening their society's rules, even if you don't live in their society--- they hold that it is morally good for people, all people even ones not in their society, to be slavers. By not following that edict, you are denying their society's beliefs, something you claim you cannot do on any moral level. You can say that their society isn't ordered well or that its unstable, or any other argument about the practicality or order of slavery, but you can't make any moral argument, to do so appeals to a moral value which can extend beyond cultural or societal limits I can say that there is nothing of moral weight that applies to black people which does not also apply to me, the color of their skin can't be the factor-- because i would have to make myself a slave to the next person of lighter skin color to myself. if you prefer, here's Lincoln's fragment on slavery that illustrates my point: You say A. is white and B. is black. It is color, then; the lighter, having the right to enslave the darker? Take care. By this rule you are to be slave to the first man you meet, with a fairer skin than your own. You do not mean color, exactly? You mean the whites are intellectually the superior of the blacks, and therefore have the right to enslave them? Take care again. By this rule, you are to be slave to the first man you meet with an intellect superior to your own. But, you say, it is a question of interest; and if you can make it your interest, you have the right to enslave another. Very well. And if he can make it his interest, he has the right to enslave you. I am able to make this argument because i can claim that principles extend beyond society and exist as logical truths which apply to everyone.

Today's post: the pros and cons of TV well, its been almost two months since i moved in and i still haven't gotten around to setting up a cable service. This marks the longest i've ever gone without access to T.V. (i don't count watching the 9000 odd chanels of crapola at Jon's place, especially when Toolie McTool is around.) Its strange how much the boob tube has invaded our culture-- they're so commonplace, remember that a scant thirty years ago, a color tv was a luxury reserved for the upper midde class and up. Now its considered by many (especially collegestudents) to be a necessary part of life. has it changed our lives for the better? That remains to be seen. so here's my thoughts on the matter: The need for escapism is a basic part of the human psyche. some seek drugs, some seek tv, but i think the idea is the same, its a way to pretend, in some small way an for a short period of time, that your life is full of really neat things. I realize this more than ever. . . having spent hours wtching the same DVDs and Videos over and over (my primary favs. lately have been the new version of DUNE, Lord of the Rings, Vampire Hunter D, and its sequel Vampire Hunter D: Bloodlust, Harry Potter, and the Count of Monte Cristo.) I think that's healthy to some extent; the ability to imagine other things and better lives forces us to strive to improve our own situation. BUt at the same time Television is a double edged sword, it also acts as a crutch-- after years of being a dedicated TV watcher, at first i found it difficult to picture anything along those lines without a TV. My subsequent attempts at creative witing and to some extent this blog is a means of overcomming that imaginative malaise. I think Dennis Miller summed it up when he said that "by the year 2015, via the means of virtual reality, any man will be able to simulate sex with any woman. The day that an unemployed construction worker sitting in a barca lounger and a channel flicker in one hand, a forester's in the other can fuck Claudia Schiffer for $19.95 a night, it'll make Crack look like Sanka." True dat, tv, ike many other forms of escapism can be woefully addictive, and it'll make people soft in many, many different ways (except one, as Prof. Miller points out, he he he) STill, i do feel somewhat disconnected from the world; i didn't know until today who was in the World Series. Television can be an amazing source of information, and i do like to keep up to date on current events. in the end, lke most things, TV is all in the way we use it: Education or Pornography.

ok, so I've been hearing so much about the APDA audit thing, and i checked my old email box to find that i hadn't gotten any of the emails. . . only when i checked my "junk mail" folder did i find where they had gone to if the quality of these emails is any indication, the junk mail folder is right where my subscription to APDAnet belongs. the only thing of quality said in any of the plethora of posts clogging my junk mail folder and taking up space on my hotmail email space was by Tim W. when he said that the quality of tournaments has degenerated lately. Running on-time is a big example. I remember when the latest run tournament got out at 6pm. Now its commonplace not to finish until 8 or even later the banquets were catered events are now pizza or other fast food. I think y'all should add another -oty award, the Tournament of the Year. let people compete to be the best, not just compete to see who can run the longest tournament. I think that extends beyond just tournaments to the quality of debate on APDA. I may never have been a great debator, but it seems like people now are too interested in winning the round to win the round--- that is, people are too concerned with finding a way to win the round without arguing the issues, arguing "the tactical" as it were. On gov, this means running cases that snug out any debate that might be controversial, giving yourself the better ground. On opp this means calling cases tight etc. Last year's final round at nats should be our exemplar of a fine round. Although i think it was a bit of a trouncing, my hat's off to NYU for running a wide open case, accepting all arguements, good and bad, that their side might entail. no caviats, no bullshit, just debate. That's what APDA used to be. it is but a poor shadow of what it once was.

Woe to you, web-traveler, for you have happened upon the rambling and strange world of Jordan Benjamin Gabriel Segal. Well, I've done it. I've finally given in and joined Blogworld. I suppose it was inevitable, but still, i am perpetually intimidated by all things technological, so i held out for a long time. so, what should i post on my first post? Well, i think a few words about my self, and what I want this place to be is in order. WHO AM I? That's a difficult question, for anyone, to answer. For me, i suppose its a little difficult becaue my life is in. . . shall I say. . . a mild state of disaray. I just graduated-- thank you, thank you-- from Amherst COllege (Cum Laude, just to tell you I'm pretentious) and now am trying to join the job market. Needless to say, that with a degree in Political Science and Philosophy, my skill set is less than marketable, and law school seems pre-ordained, but i need some time to figure out what i actually want to do. Still, i've found a decent gig, working middle management, in a firm that insists that its not a dot-com (if it quacks like a duck. . . ) So what do I do for fun. . . well, again that's a difficult question. Most of the things that i did . . . ahem. . . recreationally or habitually, seem so. . . college. i'm trying to become a productive member of society and it seems like many of those things are counter productive to that goal. So what DO I do for fun? I play the guitar, trying to get back to the skill level i was at before i put it down almost four years ago now. Oh, and i've developed a new strange hobby-- writing. NO, I DON'T MEAN THIS MEANINGLESSNESS but i've actually started writing some silly short stories and such. I'm never going to publish any of it, but its seems like a healthy outlet for. . .whatever. I've also been reading a lot, since i don't have cable-- actually i don't even miss cable anymore, except for on sundays and monday nights (GO GIANTS). I'm living in a single room in Brighton MA, i call the place THE BATCAVE-- its a nice studio in the basement of a condo, but its a cave, nonetheless-- flashback to Invisible Man anyone? WHY IS THIS PLACE CALLED.THE UNEXAMINED LIFE? the unexamined life, afterall isn't worth living. Does that mean the Unexamined Life isn't worth reading? abso-tuting-lutely. this place is going to be a place for MY thoughts, MY ramblings, and is going to be MY outlet. YOU have nothing to do with it. read it, if it pleases you, or don't, its all the same to me. is that callous? In response to Gavin's plan (posted in my guestbook): Scalia didn't recognize an absolute right to privacy. . . i think you can acknowledge that the framers intended some type of right to privacy without saying that this particular action is protected. . . . see, for example: a man doesn't have the right to molest a 10 yr old girl, even if its in the privacy of his own bedroom. I think that's an important distinction. "scalia's formulation of looking at the right at the most specific level and determining whether it is part of our nation's history and tradition is flawed from the start, if you define the right as homosexual sex, sure there is no history and tradition, and you get an easy out, it takes no account for social change and cultural evolution, and how do you ultimately say the right to own slaves is not fundamental, because by that calculus it clearly could be" i'm not sure we should take social evolution into account into our court rulings. . . i never did understand the appeal of a "flexible constitution." doesn't it make more sense to have a rigid constitution that still allows for an amendment process; note: we did outlaw slavery through an amendment (2 actually: 13 and 14). So this will probably be my last post until Heidi gets back from maternity leave, so i thought i'd give all you 'peeps' somehting you can use, something i've learned from working in the Student Loan industry, and as we near the end of grace period for those of you who just graduated, I thought i might give my advice on how to save money on your student loans. first, and this is the most important piece of advice i can give, and its also stupidly simple: MAKE SURE YOU FILL OUT ALL THE FORMS. I can't tell you how many loans i've seen go into default because someone forgot to include a W2, or forgot to sign a check, or something really simple like that. Even a single missed or late payment can end up costing you a few hundred dollars in interest. 2) investigate your options, especially your repayment options: the standard 10 year/120 month repayment option is the cheapest, in the long run, in that you pay the least ammount of interest. however, there are a few other plans that, while maybe cost more in the long run, lower your monthly payments: Extended, income sensitive, etc. . . 3) if you have a problem call your creditor. most creditors will allow you to make temporary reduced payment arragements, (TRPAs) or Reduced Payment schemes, (RPS). i guess the best thing to do is keep in touch with your creditor, people tend to just make late payments or miss payments and think that they can get away with it if they duck the creditor calls. That is just the wrong way of dealing with it. Most companies will forgive a late or missed payment or two IF YOU LET THEM KNOW. What companies fear is that the debtor will just disappear and never pay again. if you keep in touch, they tend to give you more latitude. In general people don't realize how important repaying student loans are, many people think that its not like a regular loan, which can end up getting your stuff repo-ed. . . they can't repo your education, after all. However, loan creditors and insurers have amazing powers to garnish your salary, lien your house and car, even repo cars-- and alter your credit report. most guys my age don't really think about credit, because we're not buying houses or cars or anything like that, but a lower FICO score from Transunion/Equifax can increase credit card interest rates dramatically. The better your credit, the more credit card companies 'trust' you and the better your interest rates. ok, so for what its worth, that's what i've learned so far.

urlLink Sep talks about an interesting article in his post--- which i wish i had a link to, i'd love to read it. So, without a) sumerizing what Sep already said or b) having read the article Sep discusses, i'm going to give my opinions on it. Seems to me that I'm what Sep calls an 'extreme internalist'-- that is i believe that once we answer "what is moral," we have answered "why be moral."-- as i would define 'morality,' as something like "what we ought to do," or "what the good actions are." but then Susan Wolf's article poses a bit of a problem for me, where she says, as Sep paraphrases, "if you spend every waking hour working for OxFam, you're behaving less-than-admirably; you ought to take up the clarinet or read some Chekhov at least some of the time." Seems to me that all Susan Wolf has said is that morality doesn't require me to work for oxfam all the time, but that the Good entails some idea of self-betterment. How could this be? afterall, isn't self-betterment at the expense of others selfish? well, depends. First of all, i would say that I do have some form of right to my own stuff--the stuff that i worked hard for, myself, and earned through my labor-- and that giving up everything to help others isn't morally required. but more than that, I don't think that Truth (capital T-- the ideal of truth) is just an instrumental good. Philosophizing and thinking about the world and metaphysics, and other 'lofty' things are good, in and of themselves, not just because they lead to my own personal betterment. So, i would agree with Susan wolf that we shouldn't always strive for complete and total altruism, but i would disagree that morality=altruism.

so i was reading urlLink Lauren's blog about inmate tort reform, and she points out this law: urlLink shitty prison tort law So, distilled as Lauren Does , the shitty part comes down to this: "Most notably, there is a "three strikes" provision -- if a prisoner files three claims that are dismissed as frivolous or fail to state claims, that prisoner is barred forever from filing in forma pauperis (as indigent). This means that if a man is sentenced to life in prison and he does not understand the law very well, he could be effectively barred from filing lawsuits within a year or two, if he files claims that get dismissed." ( urlLink Lauren's blog ) i didn't believe it until i read the actual text of the law. . . This has got to be unconstitutional--- I know i argue against that word being thrown around a lot, but this time, there's no way this could be allowed under several parts of the constitution but i really don't have enough information to give any of the constitutional arguments, i'll leave that for ( urlLink the yalians or for urlLink Law schoollers ) so note that i'm not going to give the Constitutional arguments, just why this law should be done away with, in general. first of all, seems like its giving the legislature an awful amount of power over the judicial system. . . .of course many statutes say when you can and cannot sue, but they always allow for very strict criteria, like "you can't sue tobacco companies for smoking," or "you can't sue gun makers for a gun accident" never, "you can never ever sue ever again, if you do X." true, we do away with many many of inmates rights, forever, after they're incarcerated-- voting for example, but it seems like saying "well, we took away some of their rights, so other rights might be done away with too" leads to prisons turning into slave camps real quick. Seems to me that with a group which has no right to vote, the right to bring lawsuit should be extra carefully protected. we never want to have any segment of our population without any legal recourse--- recognize that the final check on government is the right to leave the country, but prisoners don't even have that. And its not like prisoners rutinely go around making frivilous lawsuits for fun. . . they don't say to themselves, "well, today i'm a little tired of dodging rape by my bunkmate, so i'm going to sue the warden. . .that'll be a nice change of pace." i would say that prisoners, like most people, sue when they think they have a case. It really doesn't seem to me that the prisoner lawsuits make up such a substantial portion of lawsuits that we need to bar some prisoners from making them. if its such a backlog of civil cases, seems like there are soooo many other places to limit law suits (i.e. fast food places, gun makers, cigarette companies, electric companies for dubious 'cancer clusters.' the list goes on.) by the way, if anyone is reading this and thinking "a-ha, a case" bear in mind that i can think of really NO good arguments to support this law, this would be a tighty tight tight POS case.

1st one last message to sepdaw: I don't actually think you are a closet anticonsequentialist. Rather i think that all consequentialist theories back themselves into a corner. . . to say that x is good because it has good consequences is a rule that isn't based on consequentialism. . . .you don't examine the consequences of that rule, you stipulate it (even if you give reasons why it might be true) as an axiom. Once you grant the existence of moral truths which are true not because of any sort of benefit or consequence, maybe you would assent to other axiomatic truths. for example: you shouldn't hold people responsible for acts beyond their control. don't really have to examine each scenario which someone might be held accountable for something beyond his control, its just a truism to say that a free-willed creature is responsible for that which, and only that which, he did, himself. I don;t have to say "well that rule brings about consequences that i like, or that are generally good." now my thoughts on the Organ Donation issue: Pat writes: "3. Its a better outcome than the government just requiring people to donate their organs. It seems like this is a dubious argument. its also a better outcome than roving bands of chainsaw wielding government agents taking organs at random. (although it would make life interesting) its also better than a lot of other scenarios. that doesn't necessarily make it the best outcome. let me be clear-- i do think the other two arguments urlLink pat gives are persuasive. it just seems to me that Pat needs a 3rd independent argument in for the case. "For some small number of people out there, giving up your organs is a big, big deal. (This is generally the case for religious Jews, and other groups.) Those people don't suffer the disutility of forced donation, while the organ supply is generally increased." generally people who object to having their organs harvested for religious resons (orthodox jews and the like) also object to having their organs taken out (even defective ones) and new ones put in. The idea is that they want to die with THEIR organs, the ones they were born with. Also they might object to the idea that someone else would have to give up an organ for them to have a new organ. I really think that people who choose not to be in the organ donation system on either end (donation or recipient) don't really factor into the process at all. Yes, there are a few groups of people who object to being a donor but not to recieving a new organ. but mostly these people object not out of a religious reason but because they have some viceral aversion to the idea that their organs are going to be harvested. . . once their own life is in danger, self-preservation overrides that aversion. For people like this, it seems to me that being part of the system is based only on a benefit to them--- I call these people the minimally descent people. The truely altruistic people will always give to the system, and the truly selfish will always try to free-load off the system. but i think that most people ask for, and somewhat reasonably so, a quid pro quo from the system. It seems to me that really any system of incentive to become an organ donar will work for these people, Recognize that there are very little costs associated with organ donation--- it doesn't cost anything to become an organ donar. so that's my take on the issue.

NOTE: there has been some confusion. . . my issue with sepdawg has been resolved, this post is moot Sepdawg posts to Tim's blog: "Now, Jordan wants to know how I can be a consequentialist and believe in retributivism. After all, when I punish someone without creating utility, what consequence am I maximizing? Well, like any other consequentialist, I'm maximizing "the good". A utilitarian will say that the good is what's good FOR people. I will say that the good is sometimes what's bad for people. . . ." I think th problem has been that he and I have been operating on two different levels. What Sep is wondering is if what's good can be (as it often is) bad for someone (see last line of his comment posted above) but I've been questioning that when he says he's maximizing "the good," its not really clear what that is. . . What i've taken it to mean (if I'm correctly interpreting him) is some sort of hazy general idea of justice, or benefit or something like that. What I think is that Sep is actually a closet anticonsequentialist. . . when he says he's maximizing 'the good,' he's judging that good to be good on its merits, not on its consequences. Typically (and correct me if i'm wrong on this) a consequentialist says that things are judged to be good based on their consequences-- hence the name-- that, therefore, the good is that which has good consequences. there are things that are 'good' but don't have good consequences. Of course, there are actions which have generally beneficial, or beneficial on the aggregate, Mostly, though it doesn't seem that Sep is arguing that retributivism offers good consequences other than maximizing 'the good.' what i was asking from Sep, and i believe he might have a good answer for it, but hasn't quite understood my questions yet (granted i've been unclear thus far) is: what are the good consequences of acting on the principle of 'good maximization' (PGM) that justify it as a principle to a consequentialist. It seems a little circular to say, well I believe in retribution because it maximizes the good which is, in turn, good because to do so maximizes good. its a little uniformative, wouldn't you say. Sep will disagree with me on this but i would say the answer is that what Sep is actually doing is offering PGM as a priori, that definitionally the good is that which ought to be maximized. Once he does that, he grants the existence of moral truths that aren't true in virtue of their consequences. it seems odd to me to switch back to say that everything else is morally worhty dependent on its consequences. It seems much easier to me to say that there are things that we can know a priori, without examining the consequences of it. . . for example: Genocide is wrong. I don't look at each particular attempt a genocide and ask, well, what are the consequences of this genocide? i know, without any examination that genocide is always wrong.

**warning: this is a very poor attempt at explaining what i think is a very interesting issue, but i only had 15 min to write it, so try to give it the benefit of the doubt*** So a recent post on patrick's blog got me thinking about superrogeratory acts--- actions which we would classify as morally good, but not morally obligatory. conventional wisdom says this type of action does exist, that some things are good, but not required--- charity, for example-- that its morally commendable to give money to the poor, but not obligated. note: Judith Jarvis Thomson thinks bringing a child to term is such an act-- good but not obligatory-- and that's why abortion is ok. while i am pro-choice, this doesn't seem to be solid grounds for it. but it still a plausable definition of 'the good' might be that which is morally obligated, and therefore the is no room for superrogatory acts. Charity, as an example, might be explained by saying either a) Peter Singer Style, we're all immoral people for not going to africa and living like mother theresa or b) there's no obligation to charity and giving money to others is an indifferent thing. neither seems reasonable. but perhaps there's a middle ground that can be accepted without accepting superrogatory acts. I think that charity is a good thing, and some, limited form is obligated, on the principle that helping others in need is good. but at the same time, i DO have a right to enjoy what i earn-- my money is MY MONEY, that i (here we go john locke) put my labor into. Therefore to say that i have an obligation to live peter singer style is to say that i have an obligation to be a sort of slave to morality. that seems contradictory.

So i'm not going to post about Tim's entire anti-capitalism rant-- i leave that to patrick. . . .but i do want to comment on one thing he says: "Capitalism requires that we treat people as mere means to the end of maximizing profit. Kant thinks that this is bad, as do I when I am not in a consequentialist mood. One might find a social structure designed to encourage such dehumanizing behavior unacceptable. . ." and in a comment response to James, he says: "Use as a means is fine, it's use as a mere means that Kant/I find(s) problematic. It is fine to pay someone to bake my bread. Is it fine to fire someone who has worked in my bakery for 30 years because a machine can do his job slightly more cheaply? Capitalism encourages us to go against our intuitions about how people should be treated. One would not naturally want to fire one's loyal employee. An economic system based entirely around the profit motive encourages you not to see your loyal employee asa your loyal employee, but rather simply as entries on a ledger. This seems bad. " I'm not so sure Kant would see capitalism this way, nor am i so sure this is the way capitalism really works (rahter than the way silly post-modern, post-marxists view it. . . its certainly NOT the way Marx himself thought capitalism works. . .) First of all, Kant was all about republicanism-- ever read the Perpetual Peace? he though that the goal of government was to allow for 'the good life,' in Aristotealean terms-- that is government exists as a way of free-willed, rational creatures to exist in a social setting which provides for them to achieve a moral, dutiful, life. A key part of that has to be the rule of law, which means, roughly, that if a law exists, it is enforced and followed, and fairly created, etc.. . why do I bring this up? 2 reasons, 1) simply put, "capitalism is the economic form of democracy" (Marx, German Ideology and 18th Brumaire of Louis Bonaparte, even in Communist manifesto) even Marx writes that for contracts to be binding they must be forged between 2 equal parties, otherwise its not a contract so much as one powerful person imposing his will on a weaker person. So for a contract, as such to be created, it has to be between two people freely entering. -- how else would one create an economic system where free/rational beings can get along. . . simply put, like in governmental form, capitalism allows every agent to seek his own well being--- not necessarily selfish well being, at that. I amy be wrong about this, but didn't John Forbes Nash's work on game theory show that the maximum profit is created when all the participants of the game work on enlightened self interest rather then pure, short-term self interest. and 2) In Tim's example, the employee detrimentally relies on the fact that "i worked here yesterday, i worked here today, and therefore i will work here tomorrow"-- even Tim thinks this is a bad argument, and its not hard to see why. So long as the employer has the right, given by the contract he signs when he hires the employee, to fire someone because a machine works better, i don't really see a problem. tthe core problem here isn't that the employer is using his employee as a means, but rather that the principle upon his action is based is selfishness-- a principle which Kant says cannot be universalized. but similarly to republicanism, where every representative seeks the benefit of only his constitutents and the fair outcome arrives from the negotiation between the representatives, Kant would say that capitalism allows for every individual, seeking their own gain, to negotiate freely with each other to arrive at a fair outcome. the principle of the system, itself, is to allow free/rational creatures to achieve a fair system, which deosn't mean everyone is equal in wealth per se, but equal in opportunity. So does capitalism cause people to use each other as means to the end of profit, rather than ends themselves? not really, people do pay fair wages in exchange for modes of production fairly contracted for. that's not using someone as a means to an end--- quite the opposite, I think it somehow validates the employee--- it says that this is a creature that is able to engage in contractual bargaining, something that only free/rational beings can do. to be fair, I don't think that pure capitalism gives that, but instead requires some forms of governmental intervention--- but that's a far cry away from what Tim seems to be arguing for--- also, be aware that this is the way Marx saw capitalism too; his problem was that the act of contracting separated a person from his mode of production, and that it created boundaries between people, boundaries that Kant saw as necessary for free/rational beings. So Tim isn't being a good communist in his post, he's becoming a silly american-socialist. Therefore, Tim, you are becoming more Pink than your Lucky Shirt.

to urlLink Tim makes a quick, but interesting comment about compatibilism; for those out of the philosophical loop, its the view that free will and determinism are not mutually exclusive. People who have seen the matrix may rail against this view, but i've always thought that it had some merit. Now Tim makes part of the argument for me when he says that both free will and determinism need clarification. how can these beliefs be nonmutually exclusive? well, what is free will? I don't really accept the definition that a choice is when things might have been otherwise except for my choice. For example, Let's take Demi McDemocrat. Demi is a party line democrat, will only vote for democrats, and will only support Democrat platform issues. in the next election, she clearly CAN chose to vote republican, as in, she has the ability to do so, in an alternate (sorry Tim) universe, she might have voted for the republican (if, in Kripean style, identity flows across modal realities. . .eer possiblilites, or whatever you want to call them) but in this-- the G reality-- I can predict with absolute certainty that she will vote for a democrat. A determinist might say that in this reality, jordan has defined Demi such that she will do so, and, similar to reality, the sum total of her identity forces her to vote in such a way. and, in reality, a determinist might say, that's how free will actually works: our identies, who we are, determines what we chose, and then, a stricter determinst might continue, we can see what causes those identies--- laws of physics, genetics, and biochemistry, whathave you. So, how to compatibalize these two views? well, i remember reading an article in my Metaphysics 101 class that had an interesting viewpoint-- i forget who wrote it, but they said that free will is when Second Order Volitions determine first order volitions-- that is to say, what i actually choose is irrelevant. A second order volition is a desire to be the type of person who desires X--- so if i have a second order volition to be law abiding, i want to be the type of person who wants to obey the law. the first order volition is wanting to obey the law. Free will, then, is when my second order volitions can lead to my first order volitions--- so if my wanting to be a law abiding type can lead to my actually being law abiding. notice that a determinist might say that second order volitions are just as suceptible to physics, genetics and biochemistry. but at this point it no longer matters--- the idea is that free will is created by second order volitions ruling first order volitions. Also notice that this can be easily turned into a more Kantian vision of free will--- men are free willed because we can act upon our principles (although there is an important distinction between principles and second order volitions). A few more notes on compatiblism: 1) perhaps this leaves room for my favorite topic (which i posted about a few days ago) the mystic/rational distinction--- in so far as we are free willed, rational creatures, we have choice, but there is an important way in which we are fated, or determined, to act in certain ways. God at work? that opens a whole new can of worms. 2) i'm not really sure if this compatiblism actually works. It seems to me that there needs to be a whole lot more clarification of why choice is actually the link between first and second order volitions, rather than just an ability to do either/or of 2 different actions, although it seems like it might be a reasonable approximation of the same thing. i also really enjoyed urlLink Lauren's most recent post about law, justice, et. al but i hesitate to post on it, since she quarterfinals at stanford shalacked me and nick with a case that used much of the same logic.

So i don't have P.Larochelle's email address, so i'm send you a note here. . . I noticed you were reading "the Danicing WuLi Masters," by Zukov, which i think is one of the best books ever written-- and i'm going to tell you why i think so, in very very general terms. First of all, i liked it because it was written in layman's terms. . . . i am not, nor have i ever been, a science person, and sometimes theoretical science, which i do find interesting is beyond me because i don't have a firm enough grasp of hte basics. so often i talk about theoretical science as a metaphysician would--- that is, say how things might be about time travel, or the a priority of space-time, but when comes to hard core science theory, i'm a bit inept. second, the take on Science that WuLi masters takes is really REALLY interesting, and here's what i find really great about it. . . the idea he proposes, in simpliest terms, is that the really great scientists are able to grasp the theory not necessarily by comming up with new and different equations, but by sort of intuiting (he calls it dancing) what the right answers are, and seeing the beauty of each equation, and then proving it scientifically.--- sort of an almost gnostic way of thinking that I think our 21st century scienctific hyper-technology minds have forgotten about. I think that's one of the hardest philosophical questions to ask--- put in more traditionally philosophical terms; i am a rationalist, i believe in absolute truths that are accessable by reason (yes, heisenberg, not all of them, but the big important philosophical ones are) and all that, but there seems to be something appealing about sort of a mystical view of the universe-- that there are things beyond knowledge that can be important and relevent to our lives. and those are two very difficult ideas to reconcille, and i think WuLi brings together both the mystic and the rational in a very adept way. I don't know how much you've read in it, but i liked it. . . hopefully, this may be the first thing i've ever posted that you agree with. ok. enough with the book report.

one final word on gay rights and Justice Scalia. . . . by Storey Clayton, because he said it, just so damn better than I did: --By far the most important Supreme Court decision of all the myriad ones coming out this week is the repeal of sodomy laws. Finally we're taking an actual step toward gay rights! However, I think that the reasoning used by the Court, as always, is arcane at best. Whether or not you believe the Constitution stipulates a right to privacy, I think the very idea of one (the way it's being interpreted) is absurd. Everyone's summarizing this ruling with the general idea of "we don't want government in the bedroom". Oh really? What if there's rape in the bedroom? Or child molestation? Or child pornography? The basic logic of this ruling is that sodomy might be reasonable to be considered a crime, but it's too private to deal with. This is a very bad way of opening up gay rights doors. Why not try the approach of saying "This never ever should have been criminalized in the first place, is a fine activity, & has nothing to do with privacy one way or the other"? The way people weasel out of this is with the general standard of "consenting adults". & that's a fine standard, but that has nothing at all to do with a privacy right, really, does it? Because it has to be public enough for people to be able to verify consent & adulthood. & even that standard legalizes prostitution, which doesn't seem like a good idea either. It's a big quagmire, this nebulous privacy idea... I just don't think that there's any expectation for acts to really be considered private before the law, because the law has to determine whether a crime was committed in any situation, opening it up to at least somewhat public scrutiny. Ultimately, we really need to sit down & say that homosexual sex is okay in our society, & that doesn't have anything to do with anything else, not animals or kids, or anything. It just has to do with that one thing, & it's okay, not because it's private, but because it's okay. Plain & simple. Way to go, Storey, now if we could just get you to join a meat-eating fight club, you'd be all set.

THE SLEEPER HAS AWAKENED 1) my dad just finished his work on the new movie about the Gospel of John (not the Mel Gibson one, but a competing one to be released at just about the same time. here's a press release about it : urlLink link 2) it got me thinking about a few posts ago, Unikowsky and I had a bit of a throwdown over the topic of religion. Whereas he maintains that its a "festering scab," I still say that religion is, in general, a good thing. Of course, it can, like any other dogmatic, gnostic, or relavatory ideology can be perverted by people for power (this is, actually, my father's take on it-- read his new book to be comming out soon, also read it so that he can pay for my law school education.) and NYtimes columnist Herbert (it might have been Krugman, i forget.) wrote that he finds it odd that something like 48% of americans believe that God is necessary for a system of morality, whereas something like 25% of nonamericans around the world have that belief. I tend to agree that God isn't necessary for morality, itself, although some belief in divinty does seem, to me, to be necessary for many of our most fundamental meta-moral questions. I, like most good Kantians, believe that morality, itself, is based on 2 axiomatic truths about human nature: 1) man is free willed, and 2) man is rational. the denial of either of these inevitably leads to contradiction--- try to give me reasons that you are not rational, that seems self-defeating. and try to give me reasons that you are not free-willed. again, you end up defeating your own purpose, because without free will you're not really giving me reasons as much as saying what you are programed to say-- no real argument is possible in either case. and based on that, we can construct moral views about how to act, etc. But it does not answer "why be moral." Before urlLink you get all consequentialist on me, remember that neither can consequentialism. or utilitariansm, or hedonism, or any moral system. You can always ask, "why should I maximize utility?" or "why should I want to maximize my own pleasure?" point is that regardless of your views on what morality is, there is a primary question about what the impetus for morality is. think about trying to explain morality to a child who constantly asks "why?" to every answer you give. In the end you either have to admit ignorance or just say, "BECAUSE, DAMMIT!" Its a childish (forgive the pun) example but it illustrates what i think is a core problem of morality. A few different philosophers have answered this (or at least attempted to). . . Kant said that we have no choice-- rational beings that we are, we must behave in a rational way. and here He and I split--- it seems that humans aren't always rational; and we can see, many people acting irrationally qua terrorism, or qua strong emotions, or even qua art. while i agree that man is a rational creature, that doesn't mean he's a perfectly rational creature. Socrates (and Plato) argued in "the Ring of Gyges" section of the Republic that you want to be moral because morality gives you happiness-- a sort of real happiness that material possessions doesn't give you. this seems lacking, for obvious reasons. Hobbes also said that we have no choice but to be moral, but he based his moral system on self-interest-- saying that man cannot do but what is in his self-interest. This too, seems lacking finally, and the one I find most interesting, is Neitzche, who argued that man should strive for a will-based ethos, rather than a thought based-ethos, and Kierkagaard (sp?) who talked about moving beyond the aesthetic and teleological to the post-teleological (see Fear and Trembling). of course, the problem with this is that its extremely vague-- not just because i explained it in 2 sentances, but because it actually is quite vague. but, my coffee break is over, so check back around 12:30 for more on this

Defending Capitalism: So Storey and I have come to, at least, what I think is some form of agreement about where the core of the immigration issue is, which is to say that it divides along (simplistically) libertarian/communist lines. I'm probably as much a libertarian as Storey is a Communist, which is to say not really, although leaning towards it. But since this is were both our 'first principles' lie, i thought i might post about it directly. So on urlLink Patrick's blog, i make the claim that Capitalism divides morality and wealth, by making acquisition of capital an amoral thing-- So how to morally defend capitalism? well its been done in a number of ways, here are a few of my favorites: 1) John Locke's method: the most basic right that anyone might possess, the most fundementally consistant with human nature is the right to oneself. An extention of that right, the right to yourself, is the right to your own labor (locke sort of puts these two together, in essense the right to yourself and the right to your labor are THE SAME THING.) property rights are built on that foundation. storey has already made an argument against this viz a viz immigration when he says that most of what we own was stolen at some point. For example, The european settlers stole the land from the native americans, who, in turn, stole the land from (i guess the buffalo? sounds silly, but some animal rights'ers claim that animals have all the same rights as people, that would include property rights) someone else. Therefore, the people who originally have the right to the property, and everything that has come out of it (i.e. EVERYTHING IN THE GEOGRAPHIC BORDERS OF THE UNITED STATES) actually belong to the natives and we, a bunch of immigrants stole it. my response to this, is that at some point, ownership transfered. When did this happen? As Tim would say, the line is hazy but it can still be drawn. It may be true that my ancestors did steal something from someone and it might have been passed through the generations. but at some point 'the statute of limitations' expires. . . . it would seem absurd for the descendents of the Romanovs to come to me and say, "your great-great-great-great-grandpappy was an armed robber in 1832 and stole, in equivelent money, $1,000,000. pay up." I see people who say we stole the land from the natives in somewhat the same manner (of course that doesn't justify most of the other things we did to them, trail of tears, etc.) also, there's something of a 'good-faith' exception, dealing with inheritance. If my dad steals $200, and wills it to me without me knowing that he stole that money, it sort of seems unfair to take it away from me. . . It was not MY fault that he stole that money, i was acting in accord with the law, once the money transfers to me it sort of seems unfair to penalize me. this is a lesser, but important, argument. 2) an wierd quasi-marxist (i said it was wierd) theory i wrote a paper on once: the core marxist critique of liberal rights is that it separates man from man--- that it says, in essense, My rights extend so far as yours do not (see Marx's German Ideology for more) But what capitalism also does is separate the political from the civil. . . Marx wrote about this in "On The Jewish Question," Marx, who himself was part jewish (and a rabid antisemite, let's hear it for self-hating jews). he says that waht creates a capitalistic state, as such, was the distinction of the private and public selves-- that it forces equality among all participants, at least political equality. . . because contracts are only valid if both sides are on equal footing-- otherwise its not really a contract so much as one side forcing an action from the other. in essense, marx would argue, Capitalism is the economic form of democracy and democracy is the political form of capitalism. So long as you, or I, think that democracy is, in general, a good thing, we must assent to a capitalist system of some sort. 3) Capitalism rewards the good and punishes the bad. I'm not a total zelot of "the market will solve" the way some of urlLink my urlLink collegues are, but occasionally they're rigth about it. Capitalism certainly rewards efficency. true that efficency does not equal morality, but there are instances that it does work. See, for example T. Friedman's book "The Nexus and the Olive Tree" for more on that. i see it working in 2 ways: 1) the state can often control immoral behavior through capitalism, by taxes or sanctions, and the people, at large, have control over the state through the typical democratic means. and 2) capitalism gives the public at large power over economic actors to control immoral behavior through boycotts. It just seems to me that the ammount of wealth someone has is an ammoral fact--- you can't make a moral judgement about someone based on their wealth any more than you can based on the color of their skin, or their religion, or eye-color. Good people are rich and poor. Bad people are rich and poor. YOu can't assume that just because someone has money, they stole it, and therefore it deserves to go to poor people. Similarly, you can't assume that some poor folk are only poor becuase of an institutional bias against them, so they deserve some rich guy's money. It sounds callous, but it could be they're just lazy. (obviously not all of them, but i'm sure some poor people are just lazy) This is, of course, counter-balanced by competing obligations of government to provide for "the Just Life" (which is, i believe, the core reason d'estat of government, see Aristotle's politics for more on that) To use the greek distinction, Bios (political/moral life) is predicated on Zoe, (purely biological life) so some form of social safety net is necessary. . . . i would argue that the best form is "The Great Society," including progressive income tax, welfare of some kind, a healthy and vibrate middle class, etc. . . but complete equalization of wealth. There is still something to be said for the fact that I earned $X, therefore i deserve to spend $X.

Defending the Terminator: I've heard people's responses to Arnold's gubernatorial campaign in california range from sarcasm to outrage. People have said that 'this shows how dumb americans are,' or 'how pop culture is editorially dead.' but is this really true? every personal account of Arnold Schw. . . I've ever read says that he's an intelligent, driven, perfectionistic, shrewd business man who also happens to be able to benchpress small buildings. He's not Conan, he just played him on T.V. and all those qualities i just mentioned would make for an excellent governor. I'm not saying that he will/won't be a good governor, nor have I even looked at any of his campaign platforms (i assume they're mostly 'no taxes,' 'economic recovery' etc.) What I am saying is that he is a legitimate candidate and let's look at what he's promising to do before we start critizing him for being a joke. After all, Reagan, who is an amazingly well recieved president (despite what you think of him, his popularity, especially among conservatives is undeniable), started off as a FAILED actor (people mostly forget that about reagan, that his acting was hideous) . The only legitimate argument that people seem to have so far is Schwartzy's lack of political experience. this is true. but he's running for governor, not president. experience, especially for gubernatorial races, just isn't as much an issue as it is in national elections. many governors (including Christine Todd Whitman from NJ, FDR in NY , Mitt Romney from MA, and George W. Bush in TX to name a few) were not politicians until they ran for governor. If Arnold can successfully leverage his personal fame into political capital, that's call intelligent campaigning, not a sign of stupidity.

Review of Freddy vs. Jason: since the major reviewers refused to do it, i'm going to. . . . well, The hamburger faced villian squares off against the strong silent machete weilding goalie in Freddy vs Jason. This amusing Romp has been long awaited by fans of the genre-- and are they not disappointed. Bearing in mind that the two series have been first and foremost always about Eye-Candy, which FVJ has in gluttonous amounts, we have a film that fits into the ethos of both particular long running series. One of the major themes of the movie is the cleverness of Freddy. This is something that i thought the later Nightmare movies really forgot. We see a darker, more brooding vision of the dream demon, unlike the laughing hyena version we see in Freddy's Dead and New Nightmare. His counter part, the-always-silent Jason is in peak form. We get a more inside look at what makes the Psycho Zombie tick in this movie. . . with more references than ever to the original villian of Friday the 13th, Jason's Mother. Added to all this is the absurd amount of violence, gore, and carnage that we would expect from the two villians. It seems like the makers thought, well, we've got two bloodthirsty maniacs, so we need twice the gore. and indeed the red stuff was abound. Finally, remembering that this movie is a romp, an eye candy festivus of an extraviganza, the humor is clear. people seem to be unending bags of blood the likes of which 'the Black knight' from Monty Python and the Holy Grail might be proud of. Hysterical references to old Freddy movies, with the line "how sweet, fresh meat" paraphrased into "how sweet, dark meat." and comedy ensues. Preview Trailer from the remake of the TEXAS CHAINSAW MASSACRE also looked impressive. I hope they include the "chainsaw dance" from the original.

Here's a bit of a complicated backstory to today's post: in response to urlLink Dean Esmay , Amy and I have been arguing that groups that have faced oppression in the past need not be grateful to the society that formerly disenfranchised them for enfranchisement. In the comments, I say: the point is that telling people in oft-discriminated against groups to be grateful for the rights they have (ignoring that they SHOULD have those rights, and we--the rest of society-- were wrong in taking them away) is kinda like saying, "well you should eat this dog shit and like it, because elephant diarreah would be worse. WOmen, african americans, gays, jews, and just about any other group you can think of that faces racism/biases/stereotypes should be angry whenever they are treated as a member of a group rather than an individual" to which urlLink Amy (whose site, by the way, has become one of my mainstays. . . i really need to put a link to it with the rest of my links, and if you haven't seen it, i urge you to go there.) in an after-thought writes, "Does that last comment ("Women, african americans, [etc.] should be angry whenever they are treated as a member of a group rather than an individual.") also apply to, say, racial/minority based preferences in education or hiring? After all, isn't that exactly what affirmative action is?" that's the back story. I decided that as an answer, i would need more than a comment, SO here's my answer, I would quote the simpsons, "short answer, no with a but, long answer yes with an if." In other words, it depends. There are many different systems of Aff Action, some are ok, some are not. Some, like quotas, are derisive and do, in fact, treat people as a member of a group and not as an individual. I would say that some schemes look at race/gender, and say, In today's society, people of this group ARE discriminated against, and DO hit barriers simply because of other people's racism. This particular person has achieved so much despite that race/gender bias in the world. That shows a strength of character we want in our employee/student body/whatever. It shouldn't be that you get X because you are a woman, or an African American, or Gay, or whatever. instead it should be that people should recognize that as a member of that group you have faced, met, and overcome significant social challenges. This is not to say that White, Protestant men of European background cannot have that same strength of character. It just means that, for them, that character needs to manifest itself in a different way. Perhaps it means that the white guy faced economic challenges. perhaps he put himself in a challenging educational tract. Point is, there are just as many ways of showing true character as there are of affirmative action. The right one is the one which shows that, while proud of your heritage, you are not determined by that heritage. So what scheme of Aff action does that support, well perhaps one like the 'point' system-- where each candidate is assigned a point value based on, yes subjective, critera-- in which race is one-- but also socio-economic status, education, 'extra curriculars,' etc. that way race, as a way of guaging challenges met and overcome, can still be taken into account, but is not a racial quid pro quo. I hope that answers your question, Amy.

haven't done one of these in a while: urlLink what's your cowboy bebop theme song? Also, urlLink Sepdawg comes up with an excellent idea. I leave it to him to explain the pros of his "generallity" amendment to the constitution. I'd like to see if i can come up with a way to clarify/solidify what he says, "Only amendments that refer to a principle or a class of actions or individuals may appear independently in the constitution" I can think of a couple of ways of doing this. 1) put in an amendment that says "judges exercising judicial review are to interpret the consitution as passing judgemnts on classes of actions" or something like that. . . making it so that all amendments are considered in court as general--- then a constituional amendment regarding 'same-sex' marriages would ban all marrages altogether-- an impossible scenario. 2) raise the critera for new amendments from 3/4ths to 4/5th, and unimous among states (although each state can pass it at lower majorities) -- the purpose of the supermajority for new amendments was to prevent amendments like "flag-burning" or "no gay marriages"-- to prevent a tyranny of the majority. With a harder supermajority to reach, it then becomes harder to pass amendments, gauranteeing that only really really popular ones would be passed. 3) it could be that no amendment is necessary-- if its only to protect gay marriages, perhaps all we would need to do is have homosexuality included as a 'protected group,' and apply the equal protection clause. I have to say that I think its telling that we need a constituional amendment to PREVENT gay marriage. What that would imply is that it is now legal, or at the very least, soon to be legal. I've always felt that the definition of a family is extremely important to the form and structure of a just government-- see Aristotle's Politics on that, i think he's on point there, also Rousseux as much to say on the matter. Point is that although I agree with most conservatives that both family values and character matter in politics, simply saying "i am for family values" does not mean you're against gay marraiges. Seems to me that i'd rather see a loving gay marriage than a disfunctional hetrosexual one. Sepdawg also poses an interesting philosophical question at the bottom of his post. I'll have to think about it for a while. . . his question, distilled, is as follows: if you're a nonconsequentialist, which i am, and you're driving a trolley that can either is aiming at 5 people. the only other option is to divert it to hit only 1 person. In the heat of the moment, you make a mistake and aim to the one person, do you, upon reflection, change it back? part of what makes this question so difficult for nonconsequentialists is that it presumes consequentialism--- that is, it already favors a particular view. As a nonconsequentialist, i'd say, first, that the question isn't WHAT you would do, but WHY would you do that. It is intentions that determine moral worth, not the particular actions. I've always found these 'would you save x or y' questions to be a little unfair to nonconsequentialists. Nonconsequentialism should be thought of as more a way of thinking than a way of acting-- a nonconsequentialist might be able to argue that you should save X or Y; each providing reasons (ultimately one would be more rational than the other). as I say, that's just my first-impulse-gut-reaction to the question. For a more complete answer i'll think on the topic for a while and post on it later.

Is Racism funny? Amherst Debater urlLink Dave Gottleib writes about a moment of antisemitism at amherst involving a terrible play on words of MOO (the sound that a cow makes) and Jew (pernounced JOO). as someone who appreciates an off-color joke from time to time, i was strangely offended by the joker's pun. Can it actually be that when it comes to my own ethnic background, i am not so free with my humor? In my own personal effort against the rigidity of thought and of action of PC, i have often intentionally challenged conventions by teasing homosexuals, catholics, europeans (especially the French, Germans, and British), minorities, the disabled, the mentally challenged, the short, war widows, anyone who doesn't move so well, and the Amish. I have even been known to make jokes about the size of my own "jewish" nose. so what's the problem? why did it seem so hateful when someone else joked about my own ethnicity? well, part of the problem is that when i do attack others for their ethnic origin/creed/religion/nationality/handicap/whatever, I do so in context where everyone around clearly understands that I am only joking and do not actually think that anyone is less of a person because of being a member of said group. I do believe that P.C. represents a distinctly dangerous social trend-- its a study in overcorrection for past wrongs. Racism in society won't disappear when we eliminate prejudicial jokes from our vocabulary. The problem is the underlying lack of respect for other nationalities/creeds-- clearly i do not treat people as part of a group rather than as an individual, or at least i strive not to. When I tell a 'wrong' joke, i do so with the understanding that I am making fun of both the logic of racism-- the logic that states that stereotypes can be applicable to individuals-- and the logic of PC--that we must treat every minority group as if they were a fabrige egg-- as much as the group itself Dennis Miller once noted that our sense of humor is exactly that: a sense of what you find funny and that off-color humor is a great way of collectively laughing at how barberic we once were as a group. It says that we have evolved as a society to the point where we can look back at our own mistakes and say "wow, we were assholes, its funny how bad we were." and groups who have been historically discriminated against can say, with a smile, "yup, you were, but we love ya, anyway." but none of that understanding is present with the 'Moo/Jew' joke. It is nowhere clear that the writer understands that Jews are, also, people, and that the premises of morality dictate that they ought to be treated no differently than anyone else. If this indeed was the joker's intention, than he is guilty of nothing more than a bad pun. If, on the other hand, he intended to slight the Jewish faith, intentionally and maliciously, then he is guilty of much more.

To kick off the start of the debate season, urlLink Eunich house gives a brief lesson on debate. while Adam had much more sucess on apda than I did, i would like to highlight one of the things he says. As someone who has judged many many rounds, i think his #11 is really the most important thing he says. "Many LOR's will say something like "for them to win, they must show...". Play ball with this in PMR. One effective strategy is to accept the burden cheerfully and spin your case so that the burden is met - in which case they have retroactively accepted your victory. If this won't work, explain why their burden is dumb and doesn't make sense. But don't just let the burden stand out there. " in fact, i would almost say this is a necessity in PMR. if side gov drops burden arguments, its kinda like saying, "well, we agree with the opp's view of our case." that can kill you dead. I find the first way Adam says to deal with Burden arguments-- agree with opps burdens and show why the case mets those burdens-- to be the most persuasive way to frame a PMR. Start with an overview, that says, "well side opp has gotten the right idea with their burdens, so i'm going to show you why we meet those burdens. (and maybe give you good stuff on the side as well.)" and then your three crystalization points are why you meet those burdens. often this can win you the round. on case construction, there are a few different 'types' or 'forms' of cases that can be really interesting. my favorite is the "personal dillema vs professional obligation" case. the way this works is you set someone up to be someone who passionately believes X, but who has some kind of obligation to ~X. . . here's an example: you are an abolitionist judge in the north during the 1840s. a Runaway slave comes to you and says, "don't send me back to the south," but because of the fugitive slave clause, you should. what do you do? opp choice. Eunich house seems to think that this is a 'Psychological' case, which revolves around the psychology of the individual, well that's what the case turns into if the OPP sucks. the real way to attack this case is to take it on face value, and say, "well yes, sometimes you should do things you don't want to/think are wrong, because you promised." or "the basis of law is morality, and therefore the law can/should never compell you to do something immoral." Both arguments can be pursuasive and both are based on interesting moral dillemas. a second type of case that i really enjoy is the balls out version of "X is moral." where X is something that seems atrociously wrong. for example: Torture is morally acceptable. Bear in mind that the only way for these to be fun cases are if the Gov Accepts the biggest burden that still leaves them fair ground. if the gov says, "well, by torture we're only going to say for the interests of national security, and only in cases when nuclear weapons are involved." then it becomes silly. As a judge, i DO appreciate when gov teams take on added burdens, so long as they know what they're accepting, and they defend it well. Bear in mind, your job isn't to convince me you're right, but to do the best debating in the round. If you take something that's absurd and make it sound reasonable, that's better debating than someone who takes something that is intuitively right and explain why its intuitively right. the Final type of case that I find typically well put together is the "X type of government vs Y type of Government." Williams debaters Pinkel and Gallagher excelled at these. the Key to this type on Gov is to explain the key difference, the difference in principle between the two. that way you get the best debate because the opp team has some idea what they're debating about even if they've never heard of that type of government before. so that's my take on case construction.

Musical chairs with the Law Well, its finally happened, the music industry has decided that it can take no more and has decided to sue users for filesharing music. this is very very silly, for a couple of reasons: 1) going after a few individuals to set the precedent and to scare others into not-sharing is arbitrary and coprecious. we, in debate, often talk about how a major requirement for law is that people have to know what the consequences of their actions are, especially for law. . . think about it, apda-ers, how many times have you argued that its unfair for someone to not know what the law is, or what the punishment for a particualr crime is. if only 250 people are punished out of millions of users, that seems like selectively enforcing the law to such an extent as to make the law arbitrary. while this isn't as bad as if they decided only to enforce it against particualr minorities, its still quite atrocious--- its really unfair for those 250 odd people to bear the burden of the crimes of several million others. but that aside, its not really a crime-- the fair use part of copyrights says that the biggest arbiter of fair use is market impact. . . that is what the impact on the market of your particular infrindgement is. now if the Recording industry is going after file sharers- which it is, for sharing-- which it is not, this would not fall under fair use. however, the industry is going after sharers for having the files; an important legal distinction. after all, what's the market impact from a single individual having-- say-- 1000 mp3s, even if that means they won't buy 1000 CD because they have the songs they want on mp3s. . . well chances are that they wouldn't have purchased 1000 CDs anyway, even if they never buy a cd again, the market impact is still marginal, at best. The Recording industry needs to realize that physical recordings are becoming a thing of the past, much as urlLink this NYTimes op-ed says. so here's a few idea on how the industry could change to accomidate the new media of MP3s: 1) More Live recordings: if the industry has more live recordings, people are more likely to buy them--- think about grateful dead fans; they 'bootleg' thousands of different versions of the same songs, because they're on different days. If the industry can capitalize on that trend, it would make up a chunk of its lost business. 2) More merchandizing: most of the self-recording bands (The Allman Bros Band, and its associates Government Mule, Greg ALlman and Friends, Phil Lesh and Friends, the Derek Trucks Band, and the Dicky Betts Band -- god they're uncreative with the names. . . ) have done this quite well. they charge more for Tshirts, zippos band memorabilia, and then turn around and keep ticket prices down and allow bootlegging. .. the reson is that fans will buy the merchandise simply to 'have a part of the band.' 3) flat fees instead of per-CD: If the industry charges people a flat monthly fee, and then allows X number of CDs/Songs per month, that's also a very workable model. People just don't want to pay $20/CD, especially if its only for a few songs they want. all of these are sort of generally changing the recording industry model from a consumer product model to a more service oriented model. . . at least that's the way i think the Recording industry should go.

MORE ON NUKES (posted after re-reading urlLink Phil Greenspun's blog post on nukes vs. oil ) I suppose neither my nor Patrick really addresses Mr. Greenspun's arguments directly, which is to say that the original question wasn't so much whether to invest in Nuclear power but whether or not it is wise to invest in iraqi oil. what Mr. Greenspun doesn't note is that we aren't really investing in iraqi oil, but in iraq. So urlLink Patrick outlines a really interesting project about creating node-diagrames for language. . . in effect, mapping out what the least number of words necessary to define all other words of that particular language. I recommend reading his post, as he explains it much better than i just did. according to many Semioticists (Umberto Eco, et al.) language does, in fact, inform the way we think. if it turns out that language is just one gigantic loop of reflexive defitions,(or as patrick puts it, "words are in cycles of some kind") does that mean that novelty is impossible? consider an concept X. X has no relation to any other idea ever before thought-- it is completely novel. How would it fit into you're language-node diagram? does this just mean we've made up a new word? or can there be sections of language that are completely disconnected? Or perhaps X would just turn out to be gibberish and not 'really' a concept at all. just an interesting side note. (from patrick) -What is the size of the min-word-set in English? 100 words? 1000 words? 10,000 words? According to George Carlin, 7. (from patrick) Is there any interesting variation between the respective min-word-sets of different languages? (i.e. is Japanese really full of more fundamental concepts than English?) I would imagine the variation will be culturally relative. . . for example, Inuits have 34 different words for snow, and each corresponds to a different concept of snow--- light snow, heavy snow, snow falling, etc. while the inuits would probably consider each one a different 'concept,' we probably will think of it as 1, with differing adjectives/adverbs/prepositions attached. (from patrick) - Are the actual fundamental words any different between languages? (If so, does this imply that either (a) languages need to have the same universal concepts to be Turning-complete, or that (b) the same set of fundamental concepts are hard wired into our brains.) I would assume that when you do map out this language-node diagram, you will find a few fundamental concepts that are analytical a-priori to language. for example, I'm sure that something like the word "language" is a fundamental concept-- that any society that communicates also understands that it is communicating. the more interesting part of your question is more that are there words that aren't bound in the definition of language, but appear in every language nonetheless (i.e. the synthetic a priori words) Assume that every language group in the world has a word for 'ass': pooper, shitter, etc. . . there's nothing analytcial that would reveal this to be true, but it is nonetheless. This might be a neat new way to prove that Synthetic A Priori truths DO exist. . . when we map out the node-diagram of all languages, there are things that 'need' to be in languages for a language to be a language, but are nonetheless not wrapped up in the definition of 'language' (in the way that 'funny' is wrapped up in 'joke'). congratulations patrick--- Kant applaudes you.

urlLink Emanuel , my now 1 month roommate, was telling me about his unified theory of everything and anything this weekend, over a cup of coffee on our balcony. I must admit it is intruiging. . . although i also must admit that much still needs to be explained. This will be the first of a series of posts on the subject. partly because it is a very interesting idea (even iof the core of the theory revolves around the idea of self-reference, and it views pretty much everything else as an extention of that: the halting problem, free rider problems, communal costs etc. . . are all some version of self-referential behavior on some level. I want to start with the halting problem, which E explains as follows: "Basically, for complex machines (or programs), there is no way to say "this machine will definitely find a solution (or prove there is none), given this input x". But it turns out that a lot of problems are worse than non-solvable: we don't even know if they're non-solvable! So we can keep chugging forever, until we (a) find something or (b) give up. The search is never proven futile." This is a very key problem that Emanuel's self-reference theory seems to create a way out of, or at least explains why it exists/not so terrible a problem. this seems like a technical verson of "no negative proofs" to me. that is to say that its very difficult to prove something doesn't exist (although there are some ways to do it indirectly: prove that ~x exists, and x and ~x can't exist simultaneously, therefore x doesn't exist and so on.) epistomologically, the existence of the halting problem proves something very important: that we can never know everything. in fact, if we apply the halting problem to epistomological omnipotence, it still works: we'll never know if we can know everything, and hence we can never know everything. this seems to be something like what emanuel is talking about with self-reference. am I starting to get an inkling of what you're talking about? Kings to you, E.

(simplification, see Unikow's full post on the matter.) enough has been said on that. there is still a raging blog war in the comments on my "under god" statement below. i will leave that in the comments area. what I do want to comment more on is Sep's question, " People often try to score points in arguments by calling others' positions "extremist" -- not just "wrong", but "extremist". I was thinking -- is it possible to label a position as extremist without privileging some other position or set of positions? That is, is extremism a "natural kind" that "carves nature at its joints", independently of our social practices and assumptions?" To some extent, Sep's unstated (but i think inferred) proposition is right you can't really call something 'extremist' without privileging some other position. . . Extreme is a relative term, saying that its "far out beyond something else." nothing is extreme by itself. so you clearly need something to compare it to. however, calling something extreme also infers that it is neglecting other factors which might moderate it. the idea of "a golden mean" may still be a nice idea, but its not really analysis. . . after all, "morality" may be the extreme of "minimally decent." that does not make it a bad thing. therefore, i shall try to avoid calling an argument "extremist" without providing further analysis.
