so there's been a bit of a war going on between urlLink Sepdawg and urlLink adam I think they're both wrong. or rather, they're both partially right. Sep writes, "Fair treatment under the law doesn't mean punishing people equally for equally wrong acts. It means subjecting people to equal prospects of punishment for the results of their acts, even if those results are matters of luck." and he gives the example: Person A forms the intention to shoot person B, pulls the trigger, and shoots him. Sans excuse or justification, A is going away for a long time. Person C forms the intention to shoot person D and is about to shoot him, but a fly lands on his nose at the last moment, which distracts him. He cools down a bit and never shoots D. Person C will receive little if any punishment. It seems as though it's a matter of luck whether a fly lands on your nose. Adam comes back with "intention based justice," saying "The obvious answer is that we can't prove that someone formed the intention of murdering their friend, if they changed their mind at the last moment. Lots of people get angry for a minute, plan something horrible, and then cool off; it seems that these people should be punished less than actual murderers. But if you had some kind of perfect, Minority Report-style oracle that could definitively prove that someone was about to murder someone else, and stopped the murder right before it happened, it seems totally reasonable to treat that as murder in the justice system. " Well, Sep is wrong because Intent is important, especially for murder. Adam is wrong because actions are also important, especially for murder. this is why there is both Mens Rea (which i always thought sounded like some sort of intestinal dysfunction) and actus rheus--- both the criminal mind AND the criminal act. both are part of an actual crime. there are some crimes of intent, and some crimes of action--- and for the most part there are pretty good distinctions between the two (attempted murder MAY BE an exception, i'll leave the jury out on that, pardon the pun) This is also why Adam's example of "if I run a stop sign and someone dies as a result, my crime is identical to the intentional act of murder, which seems undesirable." fails. no Adam, you might be guilty of Manslaughter or negligent murder, or some other non-murder crime, but not murder-- there is no mens rea. Because both act and intention are importnat, the question of luck becomes less important. While luck may affect the action, there's no way that "i am just that kind of unlucky that I have these murderous feelings towards someone." the Intention does check the luck aspect. while at the same time, we don't want to punish people for thinking "i'd really like to kill that swine." 2 parts, both needed for criminal sanction. typically false dichotomies can make for many good debate cases. but in this case, the false dichotmy between "intention," and "action," as the basis for law really does not.

Today is Yom Kippur, the holiest day of the jewish year; so i thought a post on religion was in order, and after the third person to say to me, "YOU'RE JEWISH?" i thought i would post my thoughts on religion and yom kippur in particular: First of all, I would like to follow the example of many of my jewish friends and appologize for any wrongdoing i have done to all of you, or any of you. Yom Kippur is a day of atonement, where we ask forgiveness for our sins over the course of the year; something important, I think, for anyone to do. It's a day that reminds us that we're not perfect no matter how big our egos get, on occasion. It also forces us think about our mortality; that some day we will die, and even if you don't believe in an afterlife judgment, its still important to consider what type of legacy we will leave behind. I'll admit that i'm not the most religious person, although i do believe in God, and I do count myself a spiritual person. I usually only go to temple once a year, if that, on Yom Kippur, and I did go this year. But some of my urlLink friends often question the existence of God, and the need for religion at all. First of all, i think everyone really does believe in a higher power, even if 1) they don't call it God or 2) don't admit it to themselves. God need not be an anthropomophized sentient being that most organized religions claim-- the typical old white guy with a flowing robes and long white 'gandalf' style beard. A conception of God as Truth, or Morality, or some other abstraction is just as valid; in fact i think that's more what God is-- the ideal of perfection or more accurately, that which humanity should strive for. That ideal is not only good to believe in, i think it might be necessary for any sort of moral system. If morality or perfection, or whatever, isn't that which we strive to acheive, why be moral at all? I think of this as the strong version of the teleological argument for God. People who claim that there is no god and that the rules of physics and nature govern all, are simply substituting a different conception of God for the judeochristian one. saying that is just as much a leap of faith as saying "allah is god," or "buddha is god" or even "Zeus is god." both make claims about that which we do not, and can not possibly, know. Science is, indeed verifiable, but only through the lense of science itself, in Cartesian circle-style, just like Religion is verifiable through its own lense. Of course, i'd be a madman to say that science and religion are equally valid-- within its own paradigm, Science is based on logic and hypothoses verified by experimentation. Religion, however, is based on revalation and is completely unaccessable to anyone outside of the revalations of that particular sept. still, the end of both science and religion, and even philosophy are the same; they're all the search for Truth. What I think is important to God is that we search for that Truth--- that is to say its the search that matters, not whether or not we acheive it, and in fact very few, if any at all, of us do eventually acheive it. which brings the question, if what God cares about is the search, throught whatever paradigm, why build a religion around faith? and more importantly, does religion hold any value? This is a much harder question to answer. . . but the answer is part of the reason why I still consider myself "jewish," rather than "nondenominational." So much of our lives, especially in America, is based on the individual. we have individual rights, which Marx explained end up separating us from each other. And to some extent he was right about that. we think of ourselves as independent agents which separated from one another, act in our own ways. But community is just as important, if not more important because of that. When I went to services last night, I can definately feel a connection with Jews around the world, saying the same prayers, feeling the same things. that's a community, and that's something special. Its also a feeling of being part of a community throughout time-- that its a tradition that has existed for literally thousands of years (5 thousand if religious records are correct.) and that's something impressive to be a part of too. More in particular the Jewish faith is something that I am proud to be a part of. We are a group that has been discriminated against by everyone-- and I'm not going to get into a "we were discriminated against more than you" debate with anyone. . . but suffice to say that many many people have tried to wipe us out, and every time, Jews are able to survive with a grim determination. We were slaves in Egypt, we were slaves in Greece and Rome, and from Masada to the Holocaust, from the Greeks to the Soviets, everyone has hated the jews, but every generation we're able to survive. That's also something I want to identify with.

Lately i've been ranting and sassing various public figures, and while Ann Coulter and Maureen Dowd, both of whom set the cause of womens liberation back at least sixty years by showing why some women, at least don't deserve the right to life, let alone the right to vote. but sassing aside, i'd like to take a moment to comment on a more philosophical level about julian sanchez. well, less about urlLink Julian , and more about his recent article in urlLink Reason . Read the article. I find it-- and the linked articles its based on really interesting. First of all, Julian has posted on the topic of generational political trends before and i enjoyed the earlier posts (i couldn't find them with a cursory search, so look a little yourself, they're neat.) but i do, surprise surprise, have a few comments to make. 1) "A May article in The New York Times Magazineone whose author will doubtless burn in one of hell's warmer and more feces-filled concentric circles for coining the term "Young Hipublicans"claimed that conservatism is becoming mainstream on American college campuses. In a recent American Conservative editorial, Gavin McInnis, right-leaning editor of the painfully cool magazine Vice, spotted the same trend even among his core audience of Williamsburg hipsters. " I submit to you, reader, that anyone who has said this has not been to any small liberal arts colleges recently. but those articles julian sites, being done with 'good scientific method,' i'm sure (sarcasm sarcasm) i shall give them their due attention. That aside for a moment, Julian clearly defines the two generations: "In a dramatic departure from the cynicism of their Xer forebears, Millennials harbor a great deal of trust in government, hardly indicative of a conservative sensibility. Scott Beale, author of Millennial Manifesto, attributes this in part to the political scandals that shaped Xers and Millennials respectively. While the children of the 60s and 70s recall Watergate and Iran-Contrascandals involving institutional abuse of powersay "scandal" to 80s babies and they're likely to think of the furor over an intern's position on the presidential staff. "Millennials," says Beale, "might look at politics and say 'these people suck,' whereas Gen Xers were more likely to say 'Man, these people suck and the system sucks.'" cool. but where i disagree with Sanchez is when he goes on to say that this is a 'conservative' trend. In fact, he so far as to quote a prof. in texas who says this is ""hypercommunitarianism" as "fascism in youth culture."" This is where he loses me. Look, there's a big difference between saying "The American System is good system," and saying "Deuschland uber allis." American culture is, was, and will always remain one that has a strong emphasis on individuality and personal freedom. Saying I "buy into" a system of rights that allows me to always critize the government, practice whatever religion i want without fear of governmental reprisal, associate or disassociate with whomever I chose is a long LONG way off of hypercommunitarianism or fascism. maybe i'm not in tune with today's millenial youth, because i was born in 1980-- the strange no-man's land on the cusp of millenial and X generations. is it fascist to have a belief in morality of our governmental system. Ask Howard Dean if he thinks our government is a just system. Ask Wes Clark, or any of the people running for the LIBERAL SIDE's candidacy. I don't think they'll tell you that "only a neonazi would agree with that." I really think what's happening is that -- and this is going to offend Julian a bit, my sorries in advance-- What Julian is lamenting is that the LIBERTARIAN Jihad of the gen Xers is passing, and what's replacing it is a return to the old 'dogmatics' of the American Founding. That's not a liberal or conservative thing. its not a democratic or republican thing. its a rational thing. but Julian acknowledges this when he says, "Today's students bridle against the academic left's assault on America and American institutionsbut this is reactive nationalism, not conservatism. " true dat, although i think it may just be plain old fashioned nationalism, nothing reactive about it. . . always remember there's a difference between nationalism and national socialism. (random quote: "say what you want about the tennets of national socialism, at least its an ethos" --Walter in The Big Lebowski-- just wanted to put that in there.) But the opposite of Libertarianism isn't fascism or hypercommunitarianism. Our government rules with the consent of the governed, it lets us govern ourselves. while Julian may want MORE self-governance than is necessary, that's a seperate issue altogether. However. What i like in Juilian's piece is the treatment he gives to the breakdown of the traditional right/left. he writes, "Since our central political metaphor is the left-right spectrum, a relic of the 18th century French Assembly that has been growing less relevant since the close of the Cold War, political trends that don't fit well into binary categories tend to be misidentified. Libertarians have long been accustomed to being labeled flaming liberals by conservatives and hardcore right-wingers by those on the left. " its true. . . I think further evidence of this is religious right/conservative alliance--- typically the religious 'right' was quite far to the left--- meaning they were reactionaries, wanting greater governmental intrusion into schools and homes; its just that they wanted greater church intervention into government too. That's typically a leftist issue. In conclusion, i might simply say that its a mistake to label any generation--- that there are libertarians, liberals, conservatives in all ages. but that's not really a surprise to anyone. It also somewhat troubles me to start thinking about groups in terms of their environments--- its quite dismisive to say, "well, he/she only believes in X because of the times he/she grew up in." and its dangerous to do so. Its much better to take all ideas on face and analyize their contents than to examine the motives behind those ideas. all in all, it was a very interesting and thought provoking piece. Kudos, Julian.

So my first question about Lincoln's predicament (see previous post) is how to even evaulate such a question. Lincoln, i think, would have probably said that his duty was to preserve the union, at whatever cost, but that's sort of less informative than what would I do in his place. The numbers, on both sides seems so inscruitably large. . . how many people died in WWI, WWII, the holocaust, all the other attrocities that Churchill said would be avoided, vs all the slaves that would be saved, all the american lives that would be etc. . . what this seems to me to say is that a life for life, or even a wrong for wrong, calulous in this case fails. first of all, there's something similar, in principle about slavery and murder. . . as Locke would say, "he who would take from me the fruits of my labor may not be assumed to stop, and would further take everything else from me." (not exact quote but from my memory its something to that effect.) point is that the dehumanization of slavery is in some sense morally equivelent to the removal of humanity inherent in murder. Perhaps a good-for-good calulation: well, that depends on the "goods" that came out of both sides. . .all very debatable-- the state of Israel (especially of late) is very contentious as a good outcome of WWII; at the same time Churchill's Pax Americana may or may not be morally better than a single state which outlawed slavery almost a generation earlier. (is justice delayed justice denied?) so then how can I decide between the two different realities. I would say that the problem of 'dirty hands,' might apply, that if I do what I have sworn to do (that is, as president to protect and preserve the constitution) perhaps i'm less morally culpable for the outcomes of those actions. (this would have been lincoln's argument, i suppose) Perhaps what i'm pointing to is a counter example to urlLink P.dawg's usual claim that deep down, when the numbers get large enough everyone has a utilitarian streak-- and then giving some example of when one person's life is weighed against a million trillion (or 1*10^n lives, where n approaches infinity) to prove his point. well here's an example of somewhat equivelent numbers, huge on both sides, in which a utilitarian calculous doesn't seem appropriate.

I am now reading a great book called "what if", its a series of essays about military history which ask, what if certain battles had been decided the other way. . . the most interesting one i've read so far was one i've actually read before for a class, written by Winston Churchill, about what if Pickett's charge had succeeded. Pickett's charge, you'll recall, was a last, desperate attempt to flank the Union forces at gettysburg, which you'll further recall, was the turning point of the civil war. Churchill argues that if the south wins the war, it still ends up (with Lee as successor to Jefferson Davis) abolishing slavery due to a boom in cotton prices in europe causing the south to rapidly industrify-- meaning slavery was no longer a necessary or viable part of their economy. The new north/south American states form a Pax Americana which prevents the entaglements which cause WWI, which, in turn prevent National Socialism from errupting in Europe. Churchill wrote the piece in mid 50s, and it might be argued that he was just trying to escape the realities of war-torn Europe, but assume he was correct. further assume that Lincoln had this foresight. what would you do in his place? no WWII, no Holocaust, but at the price of Abolishing slavery for almost a generation and the Union destroyed. my thoughts on the matter are forthcomming.

Liberate tuteme et Willy Wonka (Save yourself from Willy Wonka) I watched a childhood favorite today, Willy Wonka and the Chocolate factory, as a prelude on TNT for 24 hours of A Christmas Story. Ted Turners really unimaginative programing choices notwithstanding, I realized just how evil Willy Wonka is. There is an obvious joke here about some strange recluse who invites children to his place with candy, but Im not going there. I think Willy Wonka is more subversive than that. First consider the Oompa Loompas. The weird little men that Wonka uses as his slave force. He did rescue them from the vernicious kerns, but he now has them at his mercy. I wonder what kind of remuneration they receive for their perpetual servitude. Even if he treats them well, which remains to be seen, they do seem to be quite melancholy and somber. Also, theyre working in hazardous environments, consider that in the span of a day four children almost die OSHA would be appalled. next, consider his constant deception. He tricks the children into thinking that they are actually working for Slugworth, who is, in fact, an employee of Wonka. He manipulates five kids all day, and yet demands that they maintain total honesty with him. Then, after promising a lifetime of chocolate, he takes it way, torturing Charlie. Think about it, someone offers you a billion dollars, and shows it to you, cash, tax free, and then shuts the briefcase and walks away. Isnt that torturous? Finally, Wonka chooses Charlie to run his company, why a child? Because only a child would run it the way WONKA wanted it. Only a child would keep to WONKAs ways. Presumably this would also include the method of choosing a successor, creating an eternal empire of sweet chocolate tyranny. So, whats my conclusion? Wonka is a manipulative liar, with pedophile-esque tendencies. Hes an evil genius, who attempts to control everything and everyone. In the end this type of person strives for the only type of immortality he could achieve immortality of fame. In this display of massive hubris Wonka shows his true form, Willy Wonka is, in fact, evil.

All this controversy about Gay Marriage in Massachusetts has gotten me thinking about the gay community. It seems to me that the gay political engines have put their emphasis into showing how homosexuality is a fact of nature, rather than a choice. I can certainly see the merit in this view if homosexuality isnt a lifestyle choice, but a fact of genetics or biochemistry, or whatever, then it certainly seems unfair to treat gays as inferior much like being Black, or Asian, or any other minority, isnt a choice, but simply a fact of who that person is. However, I think this view is terribly detrimental to homosexuals. For a number of reasons. First, it might lead to the belief that being gay is an infirmity or defect. The movie But Im a Cheerleader had a humorous take on this parents thinking that they can teach, or medicate, or in some other way solve the problem of their children being gay. Seems to me that its much better to put your efforts into saying that being gay is a decision, and its a perfectly fine decision to make. Second, and this, I think, is a more philosophical problem I have with the biochemical vision of homosexuality. It seems dangerous to me to say that something is a biological fact of our behavior. I really have a problem with most biological determinist views of human behavior. The fact is that we dont have nearly enough knowledge of the intricacies of human behavior to make any type of intelligent ruling about what makes us act the way we are. In an argument I had with a friend of mine who happens to be homosexual, he argued that saying homosexuality is a choice takes away from the belief that being gay is part of who you are. Not at all. I chose to be a liberal. Its definitely part of who I am. There are many facets of who we are that are choices.

urlLink Amy talks about the recent case of african-americans bringing suit against particular companies who benefited from slavery. By and large i agree with her, the idea of reparations is really legally very silly, and I think counterproductive to race relations in the United States. most of what she writes is dead on, i'll not paraphrase here. go read what she says. however. she writes: The plaintiffs claimed that they were entitled to financial compensation for the evils of slavery because their ancestors were slaves, and that the defendants should have to pay such compensation because they used slaves. However, they never proved that the slaves from whom they descended were the same slaves employed by the companies they sued. this seems specious to me. Its true that without that final link, there's no nexus between the harm and the harmed. but, if we were to allow for reparations to be made in this form, it would seem absurd to require geneologies of this sort. A similar argument was made in the case of jews and Swiss bankaccounts; the problem was that the Nazis destroyed much of the paper trail behind them, which made proving where YOUR money went very difficult. similarly, it would seem a real injustice to fault descendants of slaves because the slave owners, fearing the reprocussions of the post-civil war republican party, destroyed their paperwork that showed them as slave owners, or that simply age would destroy such proof for them. Again, I think reparations are a terrible idea. but if we're going to have them (hopefully not) they would have to stipulate that African Americans, as a whole, are the general inheritants of whatever reparations are allowed, and as such have standing to file suit, even if they're filing against someone who may or may not have been the direct "owner" of their ancestors.

interesting logic problem i read on Amherst's Planworld: Newcomb's Problem (from today's phil 11 class): A psych prof at your school has a reputation for being brilliant as well as possesed of an enormous fortune she has dedicated to her research. One day you get a request to report to her office at a certain hour. On a table there are two boxes. One of them, labeled A, is transparent; in it you can see an enormous pile of $100 bills. The other, labeled B, is opaque. She tells you that there is $10,000 in trasparent box A and that in box B there is either $1,000,000 or nothing. She tells you that she is going to give you a choice between: (1) Taking just what is in box B. (2) Taking what is in both boxes. Then she tells you that this is part of an experiment. During registration at the beginning of the quarter, you walked under a peculiar device that reminded you of the machines at airports that are used to prevent hijacking. You didn't think much about it at the time. But, she now informs you that this machine was something she designed and that it recorded an instant profile of your basic personality and character traits. On the basis of your profile, she made a prediction about the choice you would make, and she decided what to put Box B on the basis of this prediction: (1) If she predicted you would take both, she put nothing in box B. (2) If she predicted you would take only Box B, she put $1,000,000 in it. At this point you ask her how accurate her predictions have been. She says that 1,000 students have been given the choice, and she has only been wrong once. In all the other cases, students who chose both boxes got only $10,000, whereas those who chose only box B got $1,000,000. Then she tells you to choose. What would you do?

There's a new blog war going on in my personal blogging circle-- with imput from a urlLink Hippy , urlLink a post-thesis Patrick (mozel tov), and urlLink Punky Sue Entin Patrick talks about the externalities of foreign oil, and taxing those externalites. He and I both seem to think that nuclear power is a sorely underinvested resource in the United States, largely because, at least I think, people don't really know enough about it, and consequently have some mistaken notions about its safety. . . I call this NIMBY-- or Not In My Back Yard; same principle goes for prisons, etc. However, I started thinking about the Oil thing-- obviously its good that we start switching over from foreign, especially middleast, oil. but I have several concerns. 1) Geopolitical: Oil is basically the cash crop of the mid-east, which is largely in a state of, at least, lesser wealth for its masses. Oil profits essentially fall into the hands of the elites, aristocrats, nobility, politicians etc. in OPEC nations. This has some obvious downsides-- the people end up in a state of near-surfdom, anti-US aristocrats fund terrorists, many other bad things. But if those profits suddenly dropped, wouldn't the region massively destabilize? Saudi Arabia isn't the cleanest ally, in fact I think they're quite bad, but they're better than the alternative, surely, and certainly better than an economic collapse in the region. Think about if the area suddenly destabilizes, creating power vacuum. who would come to power? its possible that there would be a big move to overthrow the government into a more democratic form, but it seems more likely that it would end up more repressive, more anti-american, more fundamentalist. 2) Environmental: as we move away from foreign oil, and alternative power is not yet ready for widespread use, we'll inevitably begin to drill more domestically. Patrick claims to hate ANWAR-- and I can't wait to hear his analysis, but I'm also going to pre-empt it. Look, by most experts' claims, there's only maybe 10-12 years worth of oil hidden under the wildlife refuge--and I suspect its much less. Does it really make all that much sense to trash one of the few completely pristine environments left on the planet for such a small profit of oil? As we start to learn more about the environment, we really are learning how closely related all global ecosystems are. The burning of the rain forests are causing GLOBAL effects. The arctic is a place where there are special spawning grounds, turtle nests, and tons of other really important places to migratory animals, and if anything happens, it could have drastic effects, going right up the food chain. So these two concerns mean that we can't get away from foreign oil that quickly anyway. So we have some time to work with. I'd say that we should 1) largely deregulate utilities-- not California style, but deregulate nontheless. and 2) put R&D into Nuclear, Fast Breeder, Solar, Wind, geothermal, etc. . . So as it turns out, most alternative power supplies (esp. wind and Solar) don't work well on wide scale use, which, because of America's utility model, prevents their widespread introduction. However, its actually quite easy to use solar power to power, say, a single household. which brings me to Nuclear. I really think we should take a page from the East Asians, and start really using our nuclear power. Nuclear waste now can be reprocessed, not infinitely, but into the DISTANT future, far enough that, my guess is, by the time our current stockpiles of spent fuel is used up we will have some entirely new way of powering things (cold fusion? who knows. . .we're talking a few hundred years). because these new ways of producing electricity are not yet ready for use, it will give the middle east some time to slowly adjust and develop a new market, not based on Oil as a primary cash crop, and save our environment from drilling. what do you think, Bloggers?

i'm setting aside the "god" debate going on below in favor of the one on Patrick's blog re: urlLink taxation . I plan on doing this with a series of posts. the first thing i want to post about the question of tax schema is whether people who are wealthy have an increased obligation to society. Well, that assumes an obligation that an individual has to society. Most libertarians would disagree with that statement off the bat, saying that a person's prime responsibility is to himself, all others by contract or agreement only (even if the contract is the 'social' contract). To this i'd say that there does exist such an obligation. even in the absence of a 'social contract.' even in the state of nature, you still have obligations to 'do no wrong.' although there's no enforcement mechanism, no law to hold you back, that doesn't mean that you have the right to do anything-- as many modern political philosophers have contended. The Right to Murder, for example, simply cannot exist, for any reason. by its very definition, you cannot have a right to do a wrong-- by its very nature, a right is something that you can justfully do. and you cannot rightfully take a life without justification (i.e. murder). so even in the state of nature you must obey certain laws, to be a moral person. I think that is the basis of society, that we band together because without a government and laws, there's no enforcement of those rights. This, i think, is the flaw in the way most (read APDA) people use State of Nature/Social Contract arguments. The Social contract doesn't create the rights of man, it creates a mechanism to protect those rights. Ditto Veil of Ignorance. its not that you use the veil of ignorance to see what rights you have, you use the veil of ignorance to see what type of society you'd live in in order to maximize the rights you have protected, not the rights you have. It is those natural rights which also create the obligation of people to society. Because you have an obligation to not abridge the rights of others-- just as much as they have a moral obligation not to abridge your own rights, we become a connected society, not just a disparate group of people who happen to live in the same place. Ok, that said, so we all have some kind of obligation to each other. step 1 complete. Step 2 is that the wealthy have an increased obligation, manifesting in an obligation to pay more in taxes. the obvious argument here is about diminishing returns-- that wealthy people value money less because they have more of it-- or, more clearly, that $1 to a poor man means more than $1 to a rich man. While this seems generally true to me, i don't think it can really be the basis of a moral schema. it is, after all, a psychological judgment about how much people value their own possessions. but more than that, I also generally think that we have an obligation to pay our taxes, regardless of how highly we value our money. so it seems that our own personal psychological value we put on our own possessions doesn't really make a difference in the tax schema we set up. Comming next: what is the reason that the wealthy ought to pay more?

ok, so what have people been talking about? (see comments below my last post) first of all, I think adam's response of "well i'm agnostic about the existence of chairs, so i too am agnostic about God." is just philosophical pud-pulling of the worst kind. Look, obviously a chair exists, barring wierd matrix-like psuedocartesian skeptical-to-the-point-of-nihilistic critiques. Sidestepping the issue of does the real world exist, i think we can safely talk about the existence of chairs. God isn't the same at all. If he exists at all, he doesn't exist in the same way that a char or a table does. Its the difference between the proximate cause and the cause of causes. Or to put it more in Schanzerian thought (you're welcome, Emmanuel) We exist within a system, God exists outside of it, there seems to be absolutely no way of discerning anything about it specifically because we cannot step outside of our particular reference frame to see. Just to say that "there's no evidence that it exists" is not a disproof. especially when you consider all the good scholarly work on why God might want to be completely "OTHER" from mankind. (see Simone Weil and her article Putting the Torah before God." ) so here's a difference between santa and god, which makes it rational to say that Santa doesn't exist but God might. Santa does things which are, within his own paradigm, impossible. Santa isn't an omnipotent being, just a mystical one. he's not something which lives beyond our frame of reference, he was once a man (Saint Nicholas or perhaps Chris Kringle, i don't know enough about Christian Parables.) God is different. God exists beyond and behind our universe. This is to say that if omnipotence exists its all or nothing. there can't be a partially omnipresent /omnipotent being the way that Santa portrays to be. But also, recognize that the stories about Santa Claus can be traced down a specific line of a single religious sect-- and not a particularly old one at that-- whereas virtually every culture, every system in the history of the world has a God-figure. at the very least the human mind seems to attach to the idea of God, as much as a monomyth or hero architype. but then, adam gives us this gem: " Does their increased sophistication make them any more or less plausible? I personally find the hardline "there is a single deity and all so-called scientific evidence is a hoax from god to test our faith" viewpoint more internally consistent, at least, then philosophically complex notions of god which try to reconcile themselves with science." what? Adam could say the exact same thing to science is a test of faith view that he could say to me--- which is "prove it." there's no more ultimate proff that Science is a test of faith than there is for God's existence. I don't understand why Adam has this wierd aversion to saying "Yes, there is Science, but before science there are also things which we can't understand, one of those might be an idea of ultimate perfection, some goal for all things to strive for." by its very nature faith isn't the type of thing that can be rationally justified. but that doesn't mean the having faith is irrational. Think of it this way. I have a box, and i tell you "inside this box is either a dead fish or $50,000. which is it? it's 50-50 either way and you'll never know, for i have sealed the box in such a way that it can never be opened or its interior examined in any way." is it really rational to say "i know that its the fish," or "I know that its the money." but more importantly, is it rational to say "i can even find an answer." I have stipulated that there is no possible way to answer the question. God is something of the same sort of example. we've stipulated that God is the type of thing that can't be proven or disproven. It's not rational to say that he exists nor is it rational to say that he doesn't exist. that doesn't mean that saying "I will never know for certain, but i will behave as God does, because i want to be the type of person who has faith." is that really all that irrational?

Julian weighs in on the God question, which, if you're a regular listener here you'd know is a subject i've grown fond of posting about. . especially in response to Athiests who claim that believing in god is irrational. I've said it before and i'll say it again, please stop trying to make intelligent arguments about the existence or nonexistence of god. i don't know, you don't know. we don't know together. point is that on some level the only stance with regard to god that is rational really is the agnostic-- just to say "who knows if there's a god or not." Julian almost sidesteps this with his clever urlLink little rant about believing in Santa and believing in god. And while i think Julian was giving more a personalized recollection and explaination of his current beliefs rather than a justification of those beliefs, it still seems that something must be said on this: because Santa doesn't exist, and Santa and God have some similar charactersistics. does that mean that God doesn't exist? surely Julian can appreciate that the concept of God, or ultimate perfection/goodness/whathaveyou is something that, in the end, is more complex than a simple afterlife judge/jury/executioner. remember that the idea of judgement is a very particular view of what God is. many religions have no mechanism for afterlife judgement. Once again the point is not that there is a god, or there isn't a god. but its to say that, strictly speaking, its no more irrational to believe in god than not to. both sides make assumptions that cannot possibly be verified by any living creature, certainly not by YOU,

I'm sure this isn't an original comparison-- meaning i'm sure that a hundred people have already done it. But i've replaced all race-notations with homosexual-notation, just to see if the logic remains constant. Door prize to anyone who can tell me what Supreme court case is being described: In 1958, two residents of Virginia, X, a gay man, and Y, another man, were married in the District of Columbia. They returned to Virginia shortly thereafter. The couple was then charged with violating the state's anti-gay-marriage law. They were found guilty and sentenced to a year in jail (the trial judge agreed to suspend the sentence if they would leave Virginia and not return for 25 years). Question Presented Did Virginia's law violate the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment? Conclusion Yes. In a unanimous decision, the Court held that distinctions drawn according to sexual orientation were generally "odious to a free people" and were subject to "the most rigid scrutiny" under the Equal Protection Clause. The Virginia law, the Court found, had no legitimate purpose "independent of invidious sexual orientation discrimination." The Court rejected the state's argument that the statute was legitimate because it applied equally to both Hetrosexuals and Homosexuals and found that such classifications were not subject to a "rational purpose" test under the Fourteenth Amendment. well can you guess which case it is? but more importantly, does the logic still hold water, as applied above? I think it does. part of the reasoning for equal rights-- for freeing the slaves back in the 1860s-- was Lincoln's line that there's no principle that applies to blacks that would not also apply to whites; so if you were to say that its intelligence that makes white people rule, then you have to let the smartest man rule you. If its color, then you have to let the lightest skinned man rule you, etc. using this same method, is there any principle which would apply to homosexual marriages which wouldn't apply to regular man/woman marriages. 1) Gay people can't have children . well, obviously there's a state interest in marriages fostering good families. but that doesn't mean that we deny marriages to barren people. also, i find this specious when the state also bars homosexuals from adopting. . . sort of a catch 22, if we allowed gays to have children they could then get married. but they can't get married because we don't let them have children. this argument makes my head hurt. 2) gay people tend to have bad families, be pedophiles, etc. this statistically isn't true. but ignoring that, pedophilia is just as big a problem for heterosexuals, like when we hear about a 34 year old molesting a 12 year old girl, it still isn't ok. As for being bad families, well, a couple of things. first, i think most of the stigma surrounding a 2 dad family, or a 2 mom family, that a child will have to endure is the fact that it is so rare. Just like single parent or racially intermarried families were once stigmatized and not anymore, eventually this stigma will disappear. but more to the point, people who argue this would have to agree that the most depraved, negligent family is better than the best and most loving homosexual family. I don't think this can be reasonably argued. 3) homosexual sex is wrong , well i agree that arguments which say "its just two consenting adults" aren't enough. . . you might say that about anything: "officer, he wanted me to kill him. Its ok, we're two consenting adults." granted this is a bit of a contentious claim, but unless you're from the NYU debate team, something about that situation leaves a bad taste in your mouth. However, it still doesn't seem that homosexual sex harms anyone else, and certainly the types of sex acts that homosexuals engage in aren't all that unthinkable for hetrosexuals. . . this is a hard claim to make, without resorting to 'because the bible said so.'-- and the bible also said that slavery's ok. so yeah, no "no gay unions" amendment to the const. i would imagine it's going to fail, anyway. i would like to think that there's no supermajority of people who are bigoted bush disciples.

"Every Time I think I'm Out, They Pull Me Back In" -- Al Pachino, in The Godfather II OR "We should not need a permission slip from the World" -- George W. Bush So, it seems my planned break from blogging is not going to happen, as the " urlLink war of 1812 " between me and Phil demonstrates. After reading the whole thing, i think the basic disagreement between us is that he thinks that international agreement, manifested in the U.N. is an appropriate and necessary reason for domestic legislation. I, on the other hand, think that the international community could go fly a kite. bear in mind, importantly, that this post is to say nothing of whether global governance, in principle, is a good or bad thing. I am actually quite undecided on that issue. But the current incarnation of a global state is woefully lacking-- to the point of uselessness. the first reason i think that is because the international community bears no consent from its individual nations. Unelected diplomats from UK, France, or even Barundi arguing about vague international precedents with unelected diplomats from the US hardly constitutes a representative or legislative body. The UN charter also recognizes the sovereign authority of each member nation, therefore precluding any legislative power of the UN as a whole. This does not mean, however, that the UN cannot have some sort of vague symbolic power. . . that it can, as Phil states, demonstrate some sort of international voice, or opinion poll of what the world wants. but what's the value of that? the world consists in many nation each voting in different ways for different reasons. Take the ICJ, for example. some states may support it because they're a transitional state with lots of past war crimes. Others may support an ICJ because they know that the ICJ will be comprised with a bunch of judges from their country. simply being a signature on the ICJ charter doesn't create any sort of statement of WHY that particular nation supports it. And statements and actions from the UN are very politically motivated. France, for example, tries to be the voice of the third world and opposes the US on principle, it seems difficult to say that statements from the UN have any sort of moral motivation. Other countries in the world have national interests at odds with American interests. the American government's first responsibility is to its own citizens, just as other countries responsibilities are to thiers. why do their interests take precedent over ours. This isn't of course to say that we should ignore the UN-- and when our actions have material reprocussions from the rest of the world, we should certainly take that into account, but simply saying that "the UN doesn't like what we're doing" isn't an argument against a particular policy. p/s Sepdawg, strict constructionism is my next post. and, related to that, LDC's defense of civil disobedience in San Fran (Storey, you may want to keep an eye out. . .I just know you're going to love it.) urlLink a NEOCON pushing to the left? urlLink I'm Weekend Update Jimmy! urlLink Take the Jimmy Fallon recurring SNL character quiz here. created by urlLink urlLink stomps .

on Amherst's planworld, (sort of like a blog), there's been a minor spat going on between myself and my old sophmore year roommate, Gavin. Sparked by Justice Scalia's recent speach at amherst, Gav argues that Scalia's doctrine of strict contextualism is fatally flawed. Personal assertions about all parties involved and personal politics aside, the idea of a strict constitution, rather than a flexible one, seems really persuasive to me. Its no longer a democrat/republican or liberal/conservative issue. there are people on both sides who would like to simply "interpret" new rights, rules, obligations and such into the constitution. Im sure for everyone who would interpret "the right to Gay Marriage" into the constitution there's someone who would put in a prohibition against abortion, and vice versa. then, what the constitution dictates becomes subject to the political whims of the supreme court, not the "societal evolution" that pro-flexible constitution'ers want. My argument isn't that we need to keep the constitution static, but that we should abide by the process set up in the constitution to create those new rules. if we leave the constitution open for any unelected, political appointee to just put new stuff in, why have a constitution at all? ball's in your court, Gav.

urlLink Brooks writes in an Op-Ed in the NYTimes (which, lately has been my standard source for blog posts) about what Bush would really say about himself if he were as eloquent as the average, well-educated, upper-class man. First of all, doesn't it fault the president for being less than well-expressed? Don't we want our leaders to be able to express themselves clearly? but that's not what i really want to talk about. Speaking as the president might, Brooks writes: I have staked the security of this nation on two propositions; this election will be about whether those propositions are true. . . Fair enough, let's take each one by one. The first is that the war on terror means we have to escalate our alert status. We cannot wait for our enemies to launch their attacks because we are a nation already at war. We cannot wait for countries like France, China and Russia to see things our way because we are a nation at war. I think few people would doubt that we're at war with terror, at the very least, Mr. Bush, Kudos for coining that term. But people have a problem with the WAY you're fighting that war. Alone, at the cost of our credibility--- the very weapon that's most effective against terrorists. You were right to say that we shouldn't need a permission slip to go to war. You'd be right if we were fighting a defensive war. But much as I, myself, don't like it, we live in a systm of international law, and that law demands some UN oversight when we go out 'aconquering. the War in Iraq was a pre-emptive strike. and, even if it was the right war, and we smashed the regime good, we're not standing by to pick up the pieces-- which is what's harming our credibility. " The second proposition is that 9/11 was not a discrete crime. Something so horrible could not grow from a small cause. I concluded that this war is a global, ideological and moral war. Some liberals have trouble grasping evil, and always think that if we could take care of the handguns or the cruise missiles or the W.M.D., our problems would be ameliorated. But I know the problem lies in the souls of our enemies. " actually, wasn't it YOU who said that we need to go after the WMDs? I think that most of the party liberals (with the exception of the Dean Faction) did support the war in Iraq, on the basis of our quick, decisive action, and then handing over control to the UN peacekeepers for international oversight. that's not what you've done. You've got to stop absurd-tion-ing that if you're against the WAY you're fighting you're for the terrorists, 'cause, sorry sister, not the case. yes, there are just evil people in the world, and there probably always will be. but you can lessen the control those people have over the various populaces by not acting like the very monster they're portraying you to be. Brooks concludes with: But they should understand that no issue matters to me deeply unless it touches my faith in God. I did not campaign as a government-cutter, and I do not feel called upon to become one. I do feel called upon to use American power to help create a freer world. Actually, Mr. President, you did. But the problem isn't the lack of cuts, its the tremendous growth in spending that even the most pro-big government liberals are hesitant about. With your tax cuts in place, that's making the government coffers a little empty. I could lose this election. Thank the lord for tender mercies. (yeah, this one is a cheap shot) I don't know whether the American people are with me or not. checking your latest poll numbers, most are not (another cheap shot) But I know our hair-trigger reputation has jolted dictators in Libya, North Korea and elsewhere. this remains to be seen. North Korea's still there, Libya is still there, both are still totalitarian dictatorships. just because they're more hesitatant to be crazy, in response to YOUR craziness, doesn't make your craziness justified. I agree we need to depose Il, but being an american version of Il doesn't help. I know that if in 20 years Iraq is free and the Arab world is progressing toward normalcy, no one will doubt that I did the right thing. that's terrible logic. fifty years ago, there were Jim Crow laws, but now, since we're progressing towards racial equality, does that mean that Jim Crow was the right thing? obviously not. Your Nepotistic and opportunistic policies in Iraq have SET BACK the road to Iraqi freedom, and only by handing over an increasing amount of control to the UN to oversee the the transition have we had any progress at all. Oh, and by the way, there's still US soldiers there, getting killed at an average rate of one per day. once again, right war, wrong method of fighting. all in all, Mr. Brooks, thanks for the critique of the president. Although I don't think you wanted it to be as critical as it came out.

If urlLink Thomas Freidman is The Man, urlLink William Safire is a God. Freidman is The Man: " [the American Soldiers'] professionalism and their belief in this mission are still amazingly high. If you want the antidote to all the creeps in that Super Bowl show, spend a day at Centcom. I promise you, you will walk away with one overriding feeling: We do not deserve these people. They are so much better than the country and the administration they are fighting for. We owe them so much more respect, so much more sacrifice of our own and so much better leadership from a Bush team whose real sin is not hyping Saddam's threat, but sending Americans to remove him without a plan for the morning after. All I have to do is see what happened to the Kurds the other day ? this proud mountain people who have built a nice little democracy and free market in northern Iraq, only to have it suicide-bombed by Islamists ? to be reminded that this is a just war. It is a war of the forces of tolerance, pluralism and decency against the forces of intolerance, bigotry and religious fascism. " I really think that Freidman has the right stance on the War in Iraq. Even if we were lied to by our president, the war, itself, was the right war, and probably an inevitable one after we failed to get Sadam out of power in Gulf War I. Friedman and I still agree that the administration has been totally reckless in its war administration. However i don't, as Friedman seems to, think this forgives the Administration for falsifying evidence, bringing power to bear over intelligence, and misleading the american populace over the reasons for the war. I find it ironic that the people who 1) defended Nixon from "liberal attacks" after watergate and 2) tried to impeach Clinton for getting a hummer are now 3) defending the president's lies despite overwhelming evidence that there was no real threat in Iraq. (actually, that's not ironic, its all related: the principles they set out in 1) and 2) force them to either say that the president lied, and should be impeached or that he didn't lie at all. That puts them in somewhat of an untennable position. the problem is, of course, that 1) and 2) are both wrong--- Nixon should have been impeached for abusing presidential power, and Clinton should not have been; both lied, Nixon to cover a massive breach of public trust, and clinton to get a BJ that never once affected his ability to be president. . . just a side note) But more to the point, Friedman is right on-- we need to start making this into an ideological war, rather than a war of power; we need to get our allies back on board by saying "we're not just here to make Halliburton and Rathyeon rich, but to make life better for the Kurds in the north, and the Iraqi people in general." That'll make it politically tenable to "unleash the bread bomb," which i've spoken of previously-- make the United States such a leader in humanitarianism that the terrorists actually fear to damage our interests because their families are dependant on US international aid. ok, enough with that. Why William Safire is a destiny. Putin has become less than a sucessor to Yeltsin, and more of a sucessor to Gorbechev in his relentless pursuit of authoritarian power in Russia. While our attention was elsewhere, Putin has put businessmen in jail for making too much money, reminiscent of Politboro style gestapo tactics of the 1960-70s. And his agents, as Safire points out, are pulling in the unstable government in the Ukraine closer and closer under Sov-ahem- Russian control. Moldavia is already run by KGB ex-aprachiks, and when Ivanov said, (quoted from Safire) "One of the major priorities of the Russian foreign policy is our relationship with our closest neighbors . . . relations with the Commonwealth of Independent States are in no way a hallmark of Russian-brand `neo-imperialism,' as some try to depict it, but an imperative for security. . . ." he sounds surprisingly like someone saying "we need breathing room." All in all, the russian democracy seems to be based more on the smashing of chechnya than real democratic ideals. That's why the expansion of Nato into eastern Europe is so crucial-- it keeps the Russian Bear afraid of the west, and give us leverage to curtail these sorts of anti-west/anti-democratic tactics. And I thought the cold war had ended.

urlLink Lauren posts about the idea of a juvenile death penalty. I've been thinking about it for a while, and i don't really see a problem with it. . . before you get all angry, let me say that I can't see any argument for no juvenile death penalty that doesn't also apply to the death penalty in general. first, its unfair, well, the death penalty tends to be unfair. I am not against capital punishment in principle, but there definately needs to be a solid examination of its implementation--- i dont know the statistics off hand, but a disproportionate number of minorities get executed. While that doesn't PROVE that its being unfairly implemented, its certainly an indication. Better to be less sanguine about killing people. But the reason why we have minors in the adult prison system is because we say that there is no magical awakeness that appears on your 18th birthday. 18 is an arbitrary age that we chose because it "seems about right." and we examine the corner cases individually. However, when a juvenile is put in the adult system, its because we've determined that he/she has an awareness of an adult, and so should receive adult punishments. if that's so, if we're going to include the death penalty in our possible sentances for adults, why not include it for people who are, yes, technically minors, but we've decided are ok to be treated as adults. again, i have strong reservations about capital punishment in general, but i see no need to distinguish between the two. p/s its quite telling that the acronym for death penalty is D.P.

urlLink AMHERST, YOU DON'T HAVE TO PUT ON A YELLOW LIGHT! In other news, urlLink Amy highlights FIRE, a website which seems to rate institutions in terms of their censorship. My alma mater received a yellow light because of the following policy statements: Faculty Handbook - Academic Regulations - A. Academic Regulations - 2. Statement on Freedom of Expression and Dissent - 3. Statement on Respect for Persons Respect for the rights, dignity and integrity of others is essential for the well-being of a community. Actions by any person which do not reflect such respect for others are damaging to each member of the community and hence damaging to Amherst College. Each member of the community should be free from interference, intimidation or disparagement in the work place, the classroom and the social, recreational and residential environment. View full policy (PDF, 28 KB). You must have Adobe Acrobat installed to view this document. Faculty Handbook - Academic Regulations - A. Academic Regulations - 2. Statement on Freedom of Expression and Dissent - 3. Statement on Respect for Persons Each member of the community should be free from interference, intimidation or disparagement in the work place, the classroom and the social, recreational and residential environment. View full policy (PDF, 28 KB). You must have Adobe Acrobat installed to view this document. It kind of irked me that these two statements gave Amherst a yellow light. first of all, these policies are clearly aimed at allowing the most speech-- preventing others from intimidating and stopping people from expressing their views. That seems to be a fine goal to me. Secondly, Amy argues that people have the right to make such disparaging remarks, and the right to be free from such statements being censored. I take issue with that. While its one thing to make a political statment of the sort that may implicate certain minorities/traditionally oppressed groups, its entirely different to simply disparage a group. statements of the latter group really don't express a viewpoint other than "I hate X group." and don't really fall under the category of public speech that deserves to be free. The Amherst Policy aims at separating simple hate speech from legitimate political expressions. Look, I like free speech as much as the next guy, but the purpose of free speech isn't that everyone can say any crazy thing they like. Its to allow all legitimate viewpoints-- viewpoints that it would be legitimate to choose for oneself. Things like Sexually Harrassing statements, racially hateful statements and the like aren't really legitimate a choice. We shouldn't be free to choose Nazism, and similarly we shouldn't be free to choose hate speech. Amherst College shouldn't be faulted for preventing it, either. also I now believe that urlLink John Dolan is funnier on his blog than he has ever been in real life.

urlLink Storey responds to the reparations debate, with Natives deserve reparations. I actually tend to agree with storey on this one. The difference being that while African's institutional slavery ended with the civil war, the institutional disenfrancisement of Natives continues. However, reparations aren't the answer here. We should get rid of Plenary power over the reservations. (and this was a debate case i ran many times, with a generally winning record. but i'll try not to fall back into the old case setup, and stick to generalities, oh and if anyone wants the case, urlLink email me-- feel free to run it, just don't run it in front of me.) So the way that government works in the reservations is that the tribal governments can pass any law they want, using any system of government they want, (with some oversight) with the caviat that any law has to be actively approved by congress and the BNAA (native american affairs). This is a sucky set up for several reasons. . . First of all, it means that the Tribal laws take years to be enacted. because Natives who live on reservations don't actually count in federal legislative elections, (i.e. they don't have any direct representatives in congress) nobody really cares about their laws. This is especially bad considering that all their money is being sucked off the reservations by Corporations who continuously shaft the natives because of the lack of oversight. secondly, it sort of generally sucks that we sort-of give them autonomy. I really dislike half-way messures. Either we should decide that the reservations need to have soverignty, and give it to them, or we should decide that they don't and have the reservations fall under State control, but the Feds have no reason to be involved--- the Feds have been shitty to the Indians already, No?

Hard on Their Terrorists, Soft on Our Terrorists : Each and every day I read the NYtimes and I see more evidence that the Bush administration is evil. I started with the assumption that the Bush type of radical, hardline, religious (yet somehow "compassionate") conservatives were just mistaken, at the worst, misguided ideologues. I am urlLink now convinced that the Phrase "Evil be my Good" hangs somewhere in the whitehouse (i'm guessing Karl Rove's office). In case you haven't read the Op-Ed contribution I linked, Bush is challenging the Alien Tort Claims Act, a law which has been in effect since 1789, and which has been upheld in many court cases-- I think the actual number is 25. The ATCA allows noncitizens, most of whom are political refugees and asylumates living in the US to seek civil retribution from dictators and foreign nationals, in cases in which the defendants have committed crimes "against the Law of nations." In addition to the cases cited in the NYtimes, it was also brought to bear on Swiss banks, forcing them to return, or at least compensate, Survivors and Children of Survivors of the Holocaust. I am sickened that my country is now considering dropping one of its greatest laws. While we are not able to act in every instance of atrocity worldwide, at least we can say that when we are able to act, we do. This law says that whenever we are capable of punishing a violator of human rights, we will hold him/her accountable. It is true that International law is vague and confused, at best. But there are certain norms that the International Community recognizes. Even non-signataries to the Geneva Conventions may be held accountable for systematic rape, torture and murder. Even non-signataries to the NNPT are prevented from developing nuclear arms. And the United States used to be the power behind the international community. The cop on the block, as it were, to enforce these rulings. Part of that was the ability of political refugees to seek redress here, when they couldn't there. What reasons would make us want to drop this law-- or at the very least eviscerate it? a line from urlLink this makes it clear. Lately, the ATCA has been used to sue Transnational companies for their actions outside the US. It is becoming a law which will contain companies' actions around the world. however, the Bush Admin, which has done almost nothing to curtail the amazing degree of Enron-like corporate crime, would have none of that. The Bush administration seeks to change that, only so that it can allow its political and economic allies to act irresponsibly and avoid accountability. And they wonder why other people in the world are doubting American leadership.

I can show off my history knowledge too. showing off, is really what urlLink this Ny times op ed is. What the guy does is make a slew of strange arguments from history that ultimately ammount to nothing more than an appeal to authority. . . well, Ben Franklin felt this way, so you should too. The questions raised by Newdow (i'll leave the important, but not-press-covered question of standing to the side line for now) have less to do with actual separation of church and state than they do with a single man's crusaide. . . "i'll take this to the surpreme court if I have to." and he did. but the phrase "under god," was added while we were fighting against the "godless" communists doesn't seem to me to be a violation of church and state. . . the stance of virtually every reasonable government man I have ever heard was that the phrase is a "pro forma" action, and that-- just as "In God We Trust," "So Help Me God" (which is an ad lib, not officially part of the real oath of office), or "year of our lord"-- we say over and over until there is no meaning left in it. These statements are not declarations of religious belief or dogma, nor do they create any entangling links between religion and government. They are simply acknowledgements of the neoclassical ethos that pervades american political theory-- that there is something inherently special about a human being, something which, for lack of better terminology, we have called 'divine.' I suppose my antipathy to Newdow is based on a distaste i have for people who think that anything they happen to disagree with has to have a constitutional remedy. Newdow seems to think that if you change the words of the Pledge, you'll change the pledge. that's just absurd. The pledge only has meaning to people who understand it in the first place. School children don't-- they say it because teacher says to, not because they are pledging to do anything they can comprehend. It is a procedure that has lost its meaning; but we continue the ritual because tradition tells us to. There is no harm in that.

Who's the Real Threat? in his recent Op-Ed, urlLink Friedman warns that if Spain continues its appeasing approach, then more terrorists will attack on the eve of elections, attempting to destabilize countries by electing more radical regimes. The exception that proves his rule is, of course, the United States. Another terror attack will likely do the opposite for this nation-- it will increase opposition to the radical President, not support. The dominant republican party, hanging on to their razor thin majority and until-recently-iron-tight-and-now-quite-tentative contol of the whitehouse, has staked its life on the ability of our. . . shall I say. . . average-joe president to fight a most unaverage, unprecedented, and confusing war. As another NYtimes OP-Ed pointed out today, the entire administration is peopled with cold warriors, who were caught with their pants down during sept 11th. They were able to grasp the concept of a hostile government in Afganistan harboring terrorists, but they have been completely unable to grasp the concept of an unaligned, hazy, and clandestine grouping of people who do not operate within any nation, hostile or not. The Administration's response has been to personally attack any and all detractors. To lambast any-- even those within its own ranks-- who dare say that they have not been up to the job, and that they have made mistakes. In effect, they have replaced the old republican credo, "Are you better off today than 4 years ago?" with the new republican battlecry, "Do you think you are safer now than you were before (or just after) september 11th." I say here, 'do you think,' because so much of what this administration has done to combat terrorism has been kept secret. One must be reminded of Nixon's secret plan to win Vietnam. But, if we agree with Friedman's logic-- and I would imagine most would-- it means that we are, in fact, safer today. Safer, not as a result of any particular policy of the Bush administration, but because they are a form of appeasement. The terrorists want more radicalizations, more leadership willing to 'go it alone,' more people who have Bush's 'strike first, ask later' attitude. Because that type of reckless leadership is what causes more terrorism, more hatred, and more disgruntled youths in islamic countries turning to fundamentalism and terrorism. That might make us slightly safer from a terrorist's suicide bombs, but it means that we have sacrificed legitimate leadership. This is what the terrorists want from us. Is it worth the sacrifice? For the Spanish, being drawn into a war that they are, ultimately, not a part of is simply not worth the cost. The war on terror has to be an ideological war-- not a military one as the Administration is fighting. While it is true that all good and just governments seem to have, at least, some obligation to fight against terrorism, terrorists, and those that would destroy legitimate governments, the obligation isn't to send troops to a costly, poorly run, occupation of a country only nominally involved in the battle against actual terrorists. But more costly than the human lives is the loss of freedom that has become synonymous with the war on terror. Governments often, and legitimately, have to curtail freedoms during emergencies. Such short term harms are both necessary and rightful-- Churchill suspended elections during WWII, Lincoln suspended the Writ of Habeus Corpus during the civil war. But the Bush's administration's repeated and unapologetic incursions into private and civil rights have gone beyond any and all necessity. 1) welcome to blogging, urlLink Jake 2) six-eight weeks begins this week. updates as they come in-- fingers crossed Finished reading what seems to be my father's blockbuster work, "Paul the Convert," about, you guessed it, St. Paul. Undoubtably some of it was over my head, but it focuses on re-interpreting the Pauline writings in light of Paul's own conversion experiences: his visons, his mission, etc. Apparently how to view Paul within the theological community is a source of some disagreement. Anyway, for an extended discussion on Paul, pick up the book (also, help me pay for law school) but I do want to talk a little bit about one part in particular that I found really interesting: the difference between Pauline and Jewish visions of the role of law. Clearly, a political philosophy buff, its not surprising that i latched onto this section. So the idea is that the Jews saw the Law-- the Torah-- as being an extention of God's goodness, so you follow the law because the law is attached to God. Paul said the primary action is faith-- not that the law is unimportant or that you ought to break the law, but that there a distinction between faith and law. For the jews, there was no such distinction. In effect, there would have been no difference between the law-abidingness of the jews and the christians; at the time christianity was a sept/heresy of judiasm (Sorry dad, i know there's subtle difference between sept and heresy-- but its unimportant for this particular discussion). However, there is a subtle and amazingly important shift in the metaphysic involved, and its a shift between what would now be a natural law vision of the Law and a positivist vision of the Law. while first century jews saw the law as a outcome of God rather than humanity's inherent dignity/moral obligations, the structure is the same: that the Law is important because of a special relationship it has to a higher ethos: be it divine or human. Pauline views of the law also resemble more positivist attitudes. While a postitivist can make claims about the rightness/wrongness of the law, ultimately they view the law as 'the commands of a soverign.' similarly, Paul would say you obey the law, because its a good thing to do, but faith is seperate, and primary, to that. I have a whole lot to say on the natural law/positivist distinction, but for now I found it interesting to see an iteration of that debate going as far back as the first century.

A few personal comments and then on to my own review of "Passion" 1) Say it ain't so, Sep: I have enjoyed reading your blog, and arguing with you. While you are "phasing" out your blog, I hope it doesn't disappear entirely. 2) Easy go, Easy come: I find Larson's blog with a really interesting post about evolution as a social instrument-- to take the place of religion. Perhaps I'll post a response here. 3) new links at bottom, Lauren and Steve. Ok, that done, Mel Gibson's new vision of the last days of Christ. I think enough has been said about the anti-semitism of this film. Patrick doesn't see it, I think antisemitism is the movie's stated purpose. However, I think I can critique the movie's take on the NT without resorting to "you're a racist" (although it clearly is.) Actually, i retract that. One quick comment about all the controversy of the movie. well, maybe two. First, I object to people coming away from the movie saying "wow, so THAT's what happened." It isn't. its one particular view about what various (not even all new testament) sources say what happened. I doubt highly that its an impartial view. Remember that 1) the early christians were very much trying to distinguish themselves from the hebraic patriarchy, and 2) the Medieval scholars (from whom we get many of the ideas about "Jesus SUFFERED, rather than DIED, for our sins.") were writing in an atmosphere where jews were being blamed for many of the travesties of medieval life (e.g. the plague.) and 2). I really hate that people are taking their children to see this movie, saying that its "righteous violence," and therefore ok. the same people are freaking out about Janet Jackson's boob. I see something really backwards about that. This is not a movie for children-- I typically enjoy violent, action movies, and i'm by no means a squeemish guy, but there were scenes in Passion that made ME want to vomit. That said, I think there's a much bigger problem with the movie. As a student of philosophy-- enlightenment mostly-- and as a jew, I've always found the story of Christ to be appealing. There is something very ingrained (at least socially, but i would suspect its a deeper, jungian communal ideal) idea about the noble sacrifice. That's why martyrdom is so powerful, even in this day and age. For you debaters, think about how often you've used the "but you'll turn {insert unappealing/dangerous person here} into a Martyr" argument. More than that, Christ was supposed to be this Iconic paradigm, and the bible is his story of awakening to divinity. The power of the christ-figure is exactly that moment where "the sleeper awakens," to borrow a term from a different mesianic figure. But Mel Gibson's movie squeezes out all of this feeling. Instead of the Glory of Christ's ressurection (which appears as an afterthought in the last 5 seconds of the film) we are supposed to feel only a wierd mix of disgust, pity, and maybe a little bit of morbid fascination. The idea that, as a martyr Jesus died for our sins isn't about the "died" part, its about the "for our sins" part. That's what seperated him from the rest, from two thieves who were being cruicified nearby, for example. that he wasn't just suffering for himself, as we would, but for the redemption of humanity. With that in mind, the movie takes exactly the wrong stance on how to portray the death of christ. But that's just my opinion.
