urlLink This sounds like a few debaters I know. In other news, Old debater Emily Garin-Clayton posted an ad for a PIRG job on the urlLink APDA forum . This reminded me of my own experience with MassPIRG, and later with NoPIRG (the anti-PIRG org. that developed on MHC campus). Needless to say I was less than enthused with my PIRG experiences, and I'd like to take a moment to write about why I dislike the PIRGs. Of course, I only have experience with the Mass, CT, and Vermont branches, so Emily, if you happen upon this, I cannot speak to CalPIRG at all. I know the PIRGs tend to be very different, from state to state. First of all, the Public Interest Research Group, is neither Public Interest, nor a Research Group. it is a lobbying organization and as such has a very particular political agenda-- which, strangely enough-- seems to be exactly identical to the Green Party's political platform. Secondly, the groups infrastructure, while all genuinely nice people-- well, mostly genuinely nice-- have absolutly no concept of political, economic or business manegment. It was sort of like working for the Reich for Governor campaign-- which i've posted about before, its a bunch of undergrads running around like chickens with their heads cut off. What they actually do is try to educate people while asking for donations, going door-to-door asking for money in exchange for a promise to try and lobby a particular law or group. (By the way, we were specifically told to ignore all "no soliciting" and all "no tresspassing" signs, i wonder at the legality of that.) I'm all for grassroots campaigning, but the way this organization does it, the "rap" the campaigners tend to give is incredibly simplistic; pollution of any kind=bad in all ways. Most of the time they simply use misleading statistics and suspect studies to come up with "credible" or "reliable" evidence bulleted onto prefab'ed info sheets designed specifically to shade the evidence their way. I think these causes are served much more credibly if they acknowledge some disadvantages of their proposals. For example, I worked on a campaign to raise restrictions on the emitance of polutants on SUVs. The fact sheets we were given, which i later found out to be a ball of lies, also ignored the fact that SUVs seem to be one of the few areas American auto manufacturers really kick the crap out of foreign imports. Putting new restrictions on SUVs, and not their imports certainly has an effect on that, and lobbying people in places like along the Houstatonic, where GM and automotive component factories are such a huge employer, without laying out all the facts, just seems disengenuous to me. Again, what I object to is the simplicity with which these subjects are treated. MassPIRG was targeting an area with a policy that could potentially put people out of work in the area, without explaining all the consequences of that policy. This is especially bad, considering that oft times the people who supported the group most were the people who couldn't afford to support the group. I would find that the people living in amazing houses with five cars in the driveway, would rarely give the time of day (except for Great Barrington-- a place for New York liberal socialites to have their ski homes. . .) whereas the four families living in section 8 housing would be much more likely to skip dinner that night in order to pay for a year's membership. Added to this was the emphasis the group puts on Upselling: trying to get people to give more money each year. Given that its a group who gets its power through membership lists, and not monetary strength, it seems like this is a sketchy goal. Remember that the PIRGs get lobbying power by saying to a legislator "look at our membership lists, these are the myriad of people who support us." Why then, would more than a token show of support be important, a dollar or two, Especially when the vast majority of the donations were corporate or foundational, not from the public at large. In the end of the day, I really don't know if I agreed with all the policies they lobbied for. Perhaps that's something that put me off MassPIRG. But MassPIRG also markets itself as a "nonpartisan" and "unbiased" public interest group when its anything but.

with that Interlude (see post re: the Passion of Christ below) done, back to Sepdawg. First of all Sep, i must commend you: you bring the sass. but don't try to bullshit a bullshiter; i'll sass you right back. In the end, an angry tone, ad hominem attacks and references to many different types of philosophies (used to make yourself sound more intelligent) aren't really analysis. But because they can be fun, I shall use them too. Furthermore, although it is true that you're probably more intelligent than the "lefties at Amherst," but then again, so are most shale bricks-- that's not an accomplishment, its a requisite for rationality. First of all, Sep, you claim that I didn't address your "flexible constitution" argument. interesting, i quote myself: 1) constitutional flexibility: this argument states that societies change, and the law ought to change with it. I find this argument suspect for a couple of reasons. First of all, I don't see how judges are arbiters of societal values. They are individuals, with individual viewpoints, just as likely to be "old and outdated" as "fresh and new." better that new constitutional rules have a mandate. but more importantly, there are certain values which don't change, or ought not to change. No matter how much society as a whole changes, Freedom of Speech will always be a necessary part of a just regime. Ditto the right to not be enslaved, ditto the right to vote. Sometimes we need a constitution to restrain an angry society from abusing or attacking a certain ethnic group, oh say arabs. Sounds like an argument against a flexible constitution. 2 actually. What I said was that the constitution ought to be a static thing, that it enshrines rules that are true no matter what type of society you have, no matter how it evolves, no matter what social values happen to arise. if that's the case, constitutional flexibility isn't such a good thing, no matter what your methodology of interpretation is. Look, sep, my critique wasn't that Scalia's ahistorical texualism gives you flexibility, but that ANY METHOD OF INTERPRETATION THAT GIVES FLEXIBILITY IS BAD because a flexible constitution isn't a good thing, counter to popular belief. You asked me to return to your original post. What you said was that Scalia's textualism is based on a faulty notion of intention; that the framers didn't have a single, clear "intention" that can be discerned (in the way that when you said "watch TV," I couldn't say if you intended on watching a particular program, or Dom Deluise, or a blank tv screen etc.) This seems dumb to me for a couple of reasons. first of all, the Framers wrote extensively about what their vision for the constitution was. We have their primary sources about what they thought, its not just a single comment "watch TV" situation. its as if you wrote "Watch TV*", and in the margin wrote a schedule of what, exactly, you wanted to watch and why. But let's say you don't like using Framers' papers other than the constitution. Its much easier to discern the intent of a statement of Moral value than it is one of personal, amoral, taste. If i were to say "i like trees," you'd be right in asking what my intent was. But if i were to say, "abridging the free exercise of religion is wrong for government to do," my intent becomes much more clear. But also, because moral principles are accessible to all rational beings, you can also reconstruct my argument, starting from first principles, and leading, inexorably, to the necessity of government to be based on the consent of the governed, and to the individual freedom of rational creatures to believe in a divinity of their own. and by the way, congratulations, sir, you can use wierd corner cases to deflect attention from the actual argument. All methods of constitutional interpretation have wierd corner cases that seem difficult. merely pointing out that a particular case results in a counterintuitive outcome isn't a real critique of anything, except maybe that your own intelligence quotient being above that of a flea. your actual argument comes later, when you say: "The framers and amenders could have intended both narrow and broad rules by the text they wrote, and that text does not itself tell us what to do in the event that these rules are later judged to be inconsistent. In order to determine the breadth/generality of the rules they intended, we need to look at their meta-intentions. When drafting Article X or Amendment Y, did they mean to solve particular problems to address the exigencies of the day, or did they mean to promulgate broad principles. Obviously, this is a case-by-case inquiry, but I think their general meta-intentions were of the second variety. In order to stay consistent with the framers'/amenders' intent regarding broader rules, we must sometimes act in tension with their intent regarding particulars. Our doing so leads Jordan to believe that we're less than faithful to the constitution. On the contrary, I think it means we're staying loyal to the constitution." This isn't an argument for a flexible constitution; you're not saying that we need to allow judges to interpret new rules that aren't there. what you're saying is that sometimes its hard to determine what IS there. I disagree with that (see above) but I don't think that's really the main source of disagreement between us. but then you say, "I can argue within any legitimate framework of interpretation that the constitution ought to be flexible in a very meaningful sense." Ok, what that says is that regardless of a stance on framers' intent, or Scalian textualism, you can state that it is objectively good to have a flexible constitution. good for you, let's hear it. you haven't done that yet. Look, a flexible constitution is appealing because it means that we can sometimes let in rules and laws which were never intended to be allowed. Sometimes these rules are good, sometimes these rule are bad. But we have an amendment process to ensure that the constitution CAN evolve with society, the Framers weren't Gods, and they probably made some mistakes-- I would say Slavery was the biggest-- and we can argue about the goodness of the constitution as it appeared in 1783. Not every bad law has a constitutional remedy. To then allow judges to interpret into the constitution any crazy thing that they might want is simply to violate the Rule of Law, and create a legislator that has constitutional authority but no mandate from the people.

Throwing the Dawg a bone. So Sepdawg has been hounding me to write a defense of strict constructionism over activism in the constitution. Well Sep, better late than never, but here goes. Within a democratic society, you don't have a right to agree with every law that's passed, you have a right to have your voice heard in the forming of the laws. That voice is expressed through the vote. However, we also recognize that there are certain laws that cannot be changed by a simple vote. Certain fundamental rights exist regardless of the will of the majority. for example, even if a large segment of society wished to, it would still be wrong to enslave a minority group, say African Americans. To avoid such Tyranny of the Majority, we have enshrined these laws-- the Laws which govern what is rightful-- into the constitution. These are the laws which govern our laws, as such, they exist as a priori to government, itself. These are the rules which delineate just government from unjust government. Ok, wierd natural law rant why? well because it sets out a procedure by which we may change, not just laws, but those Laws which govern them. As a member of this society, we are bound to respect that procedure. While this means that certain laws may stay in effect for longer than we'd like, the sacrifice is procedural justice. What, then, is judical activism if not short-changing that procedure. The constitution specifically mandates that if you want to change the Law, you have to take a lot of time, convince a supermajority, etc. An unelected judge, beholden to no people, representative of himself alone, ought not have the power to alter the character of a just regime. So what are the argument for judicial activism? (I will try not to set up a straw man) 1) constitutional flexibility: this argument states that societies change, and the law ought to change with it. I find this argument suspect for a couple of reasons. First of all, I don't see how judges are arbiters of societal values. They are individuals, with individual viewpoints, just as likely to be "old and outdated" as "fresh and new." better that new constitutional rules have a mandate. but more importantly, there are certain values which don't change, or ought not to change. No matter how much society as a whole changes, Freedom of Speech will always be a necessary part of a just regime. Ditto the right to not be enslaved, ditto the right to vote. Sometimes we need a constitution to restrain an angry society from abusing or attacking a certain ethnic group, oh say arabs. 2) Judicial morality: I actually think this might be the most persuasive argument for judicial activism, it says that if a Judge sees some wrong, that he can correct, constitutional or no, he ought to. For example, an Abolitionist judge in Antebellum America shouldn't send an escaped slave home, despite the fugitive slave clause. that sort of thing. The counter, i think, is that the judge has to acknowledge where he get's his authority to act. His position is part of a system of rules and law, and his undercutting that, even for a good purpose, undercuts his own authority to do so. I think a good analogy, and one that i've used in the past to make this argument, is when Louis XIV declared that Man has the Inalienable right to be free from economic monopolies. If Louis XIV can understand how his own argument about inalienable rights hinges upon premises which undercut his own power, he would have understood how the fact that He was making that statement is a contradiction (strictly speaking its not a logical X-->~X, call it a Shcrontradiction). ok, Sep, your go. urlLink Yet another reason why "no child left behind" is leaving behind children Something seems unfair about talking about the problems of gifted students when so many are failing even basic skills tests. However, this feeling disappears when you note, as this NY times article does, that gifted students don't just "make it" on their own, no matter what, but that they also require special treatment. Gifted students tend to grow bored, alienated, frustrated with the slow pace of education for ordinary students. One observer notes that gifted students grow up to be 'either unabombers or nuclear scienctists.' That might be a bit of an overstatement, but we might be looking at another 'lost generation' in the making, a generation of intelligent people who feel that society as a whole has failed them. in the end, all "no child left behind" does is preach the middle of the road--- pass the basics so that you get funding. With that as the stated goal, no child left behind will leave behind those on the ends. Not only, as recent studies show, do schools now prevent mainstreaming of special education, but it will hold back the gifted. What follows is a generation of gifted adults who, because were never allowed to explore their own potential, will feel constantly alienated from society. To be perfectly fair, the issue isn't entirely the fault of No child left behind. But the absurd take on educational funding has exaberated the problem-- Remember that one of the promises that the administration made in order to get the bill passed was to increase educational funding. Instead Junior has held levels constant in most places and reduced it in many. Schools, now desperate for funding to get the basics passed-- so as to not suffer MORE funding cuts-- cut gifted and talented programs (along with other things that this administration find less than necessary, including arts, music, theatre, and non-sports extracurriculars. . . just an aside). The NYtimes article concludes by saying that No Child Left Behind preaches that its OK to be mediocre. That's what struck me. From an administration that so quickly dismisses any criticism as anti-american, it seems decidedly un-american to me to preach that good is good enough. America's ideology is, and always has been, to build it stronger, better, faster. That sentiment is built into our economic system, but also into the American Drive. Notice, that in the aftermath of the Cold war, when unilateral American Dominance is being questioned, we aren't satisfied to go quietly into the goodnight of old, outdated empires. Rather we strive to find a new way for us to be global leaders. Notice that after the burst of the Clinton-era boom, we don't say, "well, it was a good run, nothing lasts forever, now we can get back to being just a pretty big economy." Rather we call a period of slower growth a "recession." This is a distinctly American drive; while other cultures certainly don't frown on excellence, everybody else reaches a point of satisfaction, where success becomes Good enough. Not for us, though. "Pippin" may teach that its better to fade away then burn out, but is that really what we want to teach our children?

Storey challenged me to explain how a vote for Nader was a vote for Bush. I think this is quite self-evident. The winner in each district (or state) is decided by plurality-- eg, the person with the most votes for each state get that state's electoral votes. this means that when two candidates are close to each other in electoral base, they tend to split the vote and let the opposition win. So, when Storey and other far lefties vote for Nader, instead of Kerry/Edwards/democrat, they increase the chance of Bush winning in that state. Now, seeing's how that works, tell me storey, you have a choice between Bush or Democrat. Its true that the two party system stifles third parties. Tragic, but its the system we live in. Until you can change the system, live in it. While the Democrat may not be your ideal, are you really going to argue that he'll be the same as Bush? maybe you think that's the case. If so, i will post a laundry list of differences between the democrats and republicans, starting with support for 1) tax cuts, and 2) the patriot act, then if you truly think they're just the same party, I'll cede the point.

I shall try to write an intelligent post about something which i know virtually nothing about: Longhorn, Microsoft's new UI, which is still about two years away. However, Emmanuel and I have been talking about it and I think i have a few thoughts (anyone in the know, feel free to correct anything i have to say about it.) First of all, i find it funny that within two posts, Emmanuel calls it "stupid" and "really excellent technology." apparently either he's decided he was wrong, or is just plain confused. Alternatively, maybe its really excellent AND stupid. both are quite possible--- see the movie Bill and Ted's Excellent Adventure for something that is decidedly excellent and stupid. Regardless, Emmanuel's most recent post on the matter does show, what I think, is the biggest problem Microsoft faces-- and then, i'm going to draw an analog to the Bush Administration. What Emmanuel says people like Apple, GNOME and Mozilla (who are the biggest potential losers of Longhorn) should do is. . . well, i'll just block quote him here: If I were Apple, I would push for XAML to be a w3c standard as fast as possible, and make a kick-ass implementation for OS X and then give it away to the open-source community. Make it hard for MS to create Longhorn-only applications by supporting the same technology Longhorn does, and then make your own engine kick ass and get it out before MS does. Microsoft's biggest problem is open-source technology, because they've decided on a strategy that requires an obsession with keeping their coding secret. They go after people who reverse engineer (or even seem to) microsoft's programming. the problem with this strategy is that if there's a problem with the coding (for example, a security bug), they hide it until they can patch it. Open source, however, has hundrends of thousands of compu-geeks working on it at any given time, and therefore is constantly revamping its own bugs. But also because open source code is just that, open, security fixes tend not to rely on secrecy-- so you get a much better theoretically sound security program, one which is secure, even if you know how it was made secure. To say that I enjoy reading urlLink Kristoff's columns in the New York Times is a misnomer. He's constantly writing about terrible events-- mass murders, rapes, systematic destruction, every nightmare that we, as Americans, are shielded from. but while the Bush administration argues over whether or not to call what's happening in Chad/Suddan a "genocide"-- or to use a more politically OK term to ignore, like mass murder, or more dehumanizing "ethnic cleansing"-- Kristoff tells, in part, the story of a woman in the area and how she has, in two weeks, fallen from the richest woman in her tribe (big fish in a little pond) to a refugee, homeless, penniless, and almost raped, murdered, and mutilated (minnow in a veritable pacific of sharks.) And that, i think, is what made his columns so powerful. There are things in this world that the human psyche isn't remotely equipped to warp around, and the easiest thing in the world-- somthing that we, Americans have become exceedingly efficient at-- is to divorce any senitment of humanity from far-away atrocities. Kristoff brings it back by putting a human face. Its not some wierd government (quote Dave Riordan, "if you're so stupid that you can't think of a good name for your country, so you call it 'CHAD', you might be in the fourth world.") in a place you've never heard of torturing some people you never cared about. Once again, its about many single individuals, each with individual lives that have been shattered. Yet, the same people who chided themselves and Clinton about doing nothing in Rwanda-- for once, i'm NOT talking about the rightwingers; although they didn't want to do anything in Rwanda either-- are now doing nothing here. In Rwanda, they said, "we had no way of knowing what was going on." (of course, no way of knowing why the Rwandan government would put in an order of several hundred thousand machetes from french contractors.) but here, there's a difference. we DO know what's going on, and still we're doing nothing. In Rwanda, we said we were too overextended; and indeed the same is true now. but we were overextended then because of Kosovo-- a humanitarian intervention which resulted in the capture and ousting of a terrible dictator. and while we did seem to oust a terrible dictator in Iraq; we don't seem to be as busy rebuilding. Kosovo proves that we CAN statebuild. I think that means that we can be held responsible in some moral sense for things that happen while we're quagmired in Iraq-- things that we could have stopped but didn't.

Everyone and their mother is talking about Reagan-- and it seems pretty split: democrats are saying that he was a cowboyistic nuclear power addict with a hardon for spending, and that he made it OK to destroy poor people, and that he paved the way for GWB's jingoist nepostist and revolutionary conservative national revolution. and on the other side Republicans are saying he had a great smile. ok, that was a bit of a straw man, but i think you can find people on each side saying good/bad things about our departed leader. as for myself, I have to say that I think he's out JFK'd JFK; which is to say he's a model of style over substance. As much as I agree with Adam (see his most recent post for a complete and total annihilational deconstruction of Reagan's politics) Reagan still had a postive impact on America. Although I was only an infant when Reagan took office, from what i've read, the idea was that America was somehow on the decline. years of stagflation from Carter (who, by the by, was the exact opposite: a good and decent man to whom bad shit happened on his watch. . . at least that's how I see it. . . i digress) had taken their toll on american ideological will (not to mention a dragging cold war, and the memories of Korea, Vietnam and the fade of the glory of WWII). Reagan's administration restored some sense of faith in the American Idea-- not the American Ideal, but the sense that our country is a city on a hill; that our system is somehow better, set apart from the rest, and as such we are meant to be leaders. I think that's a good thing, in moderation, of course. We can't assume we're worthy of leadership. Certainly our most recent actions in Iraq show we're not. but it still gives us an ideal-- an image of what we should be, what we can be, and what we need to strive for. And as for Reagan's legacy, what's so wrong with creating our own heros. We've been doing it for years: JFK, who had scarcely the popularity to match WJC at his lowest moments, has been cannonized into the last King Arthur of Camelot. In China, Deng Xioping has been hailed as the instrument that modernized Mao. neither is true, but people need their idols-- is it so important for those idols to be real, rather than self-created? Look at how we're idolizing Reagan. people are once again calling him "the great communicator," "a peacemaker" (not sure if they mean a man who brings peace, or a reference to the Smith and Wesson gun.) "a Uniter," all these things that we simultaneously need in our leaders and see lacking in our current leadership. Why is it bad to create for ourselves a hero-- an idol-- of all those aspects of good governance and leadership that we ought to require in ourselves? Let us have our graven images, our idealized fallen, and our false gods. They will remind us not what the real men did, but reflect our own wants, desires, and hopes.

Adam posts an observation on his urlLink blog saying: Lots of people have speculated as to why Bush remains popular, despite Kerry's huge leads in most individual issues (the economy, taxes, even Iraq at this point.) One idea is that the Republican party has succeeded in making the election about a "story" - that Democrats are terrorist appeasers who will ban small businesses and abolish marriage, and Republicans are the real Americans - while the Democratic party only has a laundry list of policies. Just asking the question seems odd to me. we view voting as an expression of who I want to be MY representative in congress/president/government. we certainly do attach some kind of moral weight to voting. but the question would apply to any time where short-term benefits and long-term benefits are mutually exclusive. for example: drug addicts get short term benefits from their drugs, at a long term cost. Adam, who has yet to respond to his own problems with physical appearance, goes on to talk about fate and free will. So i'd like to talk for a moment about compatiblism-- the view that free will and determinism are not mutually exclusive. I'm certainly not an expert on free will/determinism debate except to say that both do have excellent arguements. For the fate side, it certainly does seem like we can create a very coherant account of how the physical laws might govern our choices; our brains are gigantic electrochemical processing machines, and so we can say that, although we don't know how all the processes work, we can be confident that our consicousness/thoughts are relegated to the sphere of electrochemical impulses which are, in turn, governed by chemistry, physics, and biology style determinism. (this, of course, avoids a massively unproductive debate about God and fate. such arguments almost always devolve into the mystic, which, I think there's a place for, but not here.) On the flip side, we do seem to have free will-- and many of our actions and beliefs are predicated on free will: the idea that we have choices is inherent to a system of justice, etc. An account can clearly be given about free will as an emergent property (greater than the sum of its parts). Compatibilism, then, is an account which says that the seeming controdiction between free will and fate is only because of a lack of definition. And it might seem reasonable to say something of the following sort: Say, hypothetically, that Person A loves to go left-- its just his biological makeup that he distrusts right-hand turns. However, even if I know that A will choose to go left every time he comes to a particular intersection, he still has the choice--- it could be the case (without going into a ton of wierd modal theory that i don't really know) that A could have gone right, but he didn't, his choice was left. Although we can be absoulutely certain that he would make that choice, knowing what we do about him, doesn't mean that he didn't have that choice. it is an interesting view.

Adam questions if its ok to react differently to people based purely on their physical appearance. what he says is: "Everyone makes instant personality assessments of people when they meet them, and I have found that my personality assessments are accurate surprisingly frequently. Part of this is that I will react to an attractive person different from an ugly person, rendering my personality assessment a self-fulfilling prophecy; but part of it is that personality really does often correlate with appearance. " And then goes into a lengthy justification of why its OK to judge people based entirely on physicality. in summary he say a few things: 1) being attractive takes work, and I like people who work at things. 2) a silly genetics-leads-to-good-personality argument 3) attractive people have confidence 4) unattractive people tend to have self-defensive personality traits. to be fair, read his entire post, and not just the taglines i've given him. go urlLink Here , now. back? ok good. now we can proceed. Upfront, i think 1-4 are, in various degrees, based on flawed assumptions. First of all, the core problem with Uni's view is that it assumes that because people tend to judge based on pure appearance that they SHOULD do so. All four of those arguments fall away if you accept that it is in someway wrong to, as Kierkagaard (or was it Dick Van Patten) said, "label me, and negate me." (thank you Wayne's World.) and here's a few reasons why this might be the case. it may be trite but beauty is in the eye of the beholder. How many conversations have you had about "is X guy/girl you know attractive." how many times do people have vastly different opinions about that. A few examples: Ally McBeal was considered to be very attractive, but many found her skeletor-esqely hideous. Many other people find Roseanne Bar to be disgustingly unattractive, yet Tom Arnold found her hot enough to produce children with. It would seem wierd, then, to base some sort of judgement of personality on such a subjective thing. Do people's personalities change based on who is looking at them? that would seem wierd. To put it more simply, many attractive people are assholes. many attractive people are quite nice. many unattractive people are assholes. many unattractive people are quite nice. its hard to judge how a person would react to their own physicality-- and their reactant personality traits. well, that throws out 2,3, and 4. so let's deal with #1. good looking people, according to Adam, tend to be the type of person who puts effort into things, and therefore, are nice, or good people, or some other term of endearment. let's examine what, exactly, Adam says: Part of it is that attractiveness takes work, and it requires a certain kind of personality to put the time and effort into being attractive. Only a certain type of person will go and lift weights, and lifting weights makes you attractive, so in that sense, one would expect attractiveness and personality to correlate. But body shape is not the only component of beauty - in fact, I'd say a considerable portion of attractiveness is purely innate. Even controlling for body image, I think personality and attractiveness often go hand in hand Still, it might well be the case that the type of work that goes into body image makes someone's personality LESS good: more vainity, more ego, more narciscism-- its true that those are qualities that many of my good friends possess, but one could see how being a vain, egoistic self-aggrandizing ego queen might turn some people off. I guess, in summary, that I would say the same thing i say about racism: If you look around in this world, you'll see more assholes than a turkish customs agent. so why hate someone based on their skin, when if you take 5 min to get to know them, you'll find so many much better reasons to hate them.

Happy Anniversary to Storey and Emily! I'd like to throw my two cents into the small blograment (1. N., amalgamation of Blog and Argument; 2. N ., amalgamation of Blog and Sacrament) between urlLink Andrew and urlLink Lauren on the subject of Moral Relativism. Good Kantian that I am, I have a deep, deep, deep distrust of relativistic stances, cultural and otherwise. My thoughts on the matter of relativism in general fall somewhere along the lines of, well, if we can base our moral systems on something that is universal to all mankind, (eg rationality and free will) then cultural matters drop away and we have our universal truths. but let that go for now. Instead of building my own case, I want to trash someone else's. So Sep, quite adeptly, characterizes relativism (read his post). As an afterthought (where I usually find problem with what people say), Sep says, "note that it is different from moral nihilism (the belief that there is no morality in the normative sense) and moral subjectivism (the belief, often confused with relativism, that moral beliefs are only true/false in light of ONE's OWN passions). . ." Clearly relativism is different from nihilism? The view that says "morality has a property of being contrived by local societies" is different from one which says "no morality exists" only if you've already accepted as a premise a specific definition of what morality is. (you might be saying, 'Huh?' i shall explain. . ." Many philosophers have held throughout the ages that part of morality is universality, in the sense that part of "JOKE" is "FUNNY." that part of the concept of morality is its universality, or more specifically that universality is a definitionally important aspect of morality. if this is the case, then saying that there is no universality in morality is sort of like saying "~X is part of X," or saying nothing at all, if you think a contradictory statement is meaningless. that's thought one. thought two is that I'm a little confused by Sep's description separating moral relativity from moral subjectivity, because i think its part of the problem with de-universalizing moral theories in general-- note: the following statement is NOT flushed out philosophical belief, just sort of a thought that's been floating around in my head-- we can't really escape universal moral judgments, even when we're trying to make relavistic statements. For example. the distinction between relativism and subjectivism is that the society, rather than the individual, makes the moral judgment (makes, in the sense of creates) in relativism, and the individual, rather than society as a whole creates morality in subjectivism. First of all, Lauren points out the first problem, which is that it is hard to determine what the society as a while feels anyway: what is the proper percentage for a moral value: 100? 50+1? 66? 60? and what of those who disagree with the society (the other 49.9%). but this leads into what I think is a deeper critique of relativistic stances, which is: what rule, what moral law, what code tells you that the cultural is more important than the individual. The best I can think of is something along the lines of 'its more democratic that way,' but that already presupposes a democratic truth which exists outside relativistic space, in which case the relativist has already ceeded the most important argument: that there exist univseral truths. or, as sep points out, it could be something along the lines of a contract: that a culture contracts itself to certain morals. again, why does that work for a culture, but not the individual. I did not contract to any particular moral, therefore why does it apply to me. In the end, there are just too many controdictions, too many paradoxes. there must exist an objective moral code.

The recent pick of John Edwards (which, I think, is a massive asset to the dems, and creating a hugely powerful ticket-- one which, I'd play slightly better than even odds for winning in november) underscores one of the most divisive issues to the Dem party in America: Globalization. Kerry, as a successor to the Clintonites, has been pro, claims that it allows the US to specialize, and bring democratizing capital to the third world; Edwards, whose mildly protectionist rhetoric during the debates shows him as more of a anti, claims that it ends up forcing the US to be friends with some rather unscrupulous people, and allows more outsourcing. There are clear economic and political advantages to globalization-- it allows the US to cut costs by using cheaper international labor, but supply-side economics only goes so far. it does create a intricate web of dependencies which the US benefits from as much as it forces us into certain. . . strange alliances. . ahem Saudi Arabia. But on the foreign side, third world labor markets benefit immensely from American investments, specifically because they don't have as many regulations governing treatement of workers, minimum wage, etc. and that may be a potential human rights disaster in which the United States economy is complicit, or worse encouraging. But with a strong ticket that combines both pro-globalizing and mildly protectionist policitians, and with an entirely gun-ho corporate globalizing ticket on the other side, it seems rather unlikely that the United States will do anything to jepordize global capital in the next four years. Regardless of your stance on the globalization of capital, what clearly needs to happen is some form of global oversight of third world markets-- to make sure that, while values about how much minimum wage should be, or if it should be at all, nobody becomes a virtual surf in a third world feifdom headed by terrible people with penchants for using American capital to finance further abuses. But this cannot be done unilaterally- no single nation, especially not the United States at this time, has the power, influence or support to either start an oversight body or empower the current. . . shall I say fledgling. . . oversight bodies to do what needs to be done.

I saw Spiderman 2 this weekend. Wow. its quite rare that a sequel comes out that's better than the original. the special effects were simply breathtaking, and the cast is amazing-- urlLink Alfred Molina , as Doctor Otto "Doc Ock" Octavius, is more than just good as a villian, but downright scary at times. But this take on spiderman is the real strength of the movie-- that, to steal a joke from the first movie, he's not superman. the fact that so much time is spent on his personal dillema, one which haunts Parker from the moment he's bitten by that radioactive spider, whether to go after the villian or to go after his love, the always beautiful and fiesty redhead Mary Jane Watson. I recommend the movie to anyone, and I plan on seeing it again.

In this post i'm going to line by line respond to Slate's scathing review of the Michael Moore controversy. you can find Hitchen's review urlLink here Hitchen starts off with a stupidly sarcastic opening line, asking who is the Left's Rush Limbaugh. Seems to me that the only thing Moore and Rush have in common is being fat, something that also many others have in common with both of them. so after a slew of ad hominem attacks (this movie is "moral frivolity," "To describe this film as a piece of crap would be to run the risk of a discourse that would never again rise above the excremental." etc.) Hitchens gets to his actual analysis. "In late 2002, almost a year after the al-Qaida assault on American society, I had an onstage debate with Michael Moore at the Telluride Film Festival. In the course of this exchange, he stated his view that Osama Bin Laden should be considered innocent until proven guilty. This was, he said, the American way. The intervention in Afghanistan, he maintained, had been at least to that extent unjustified. SomethingI cannot guess what, since we knew as much then as we do nowhas since apparently persuaded Moore that Osama Bin Laden is as guilty as hell. Indeed, Osama is suddenly so guilty and so all-powerful that any other discussion of any other topic is a dangerous "distraction" from the fight against him. 1) it did seem, at first, that we were rushing off to blame AlQaida militants for 9/11. although it turns out to be true, Moore often points out that the Press in this country doesn't ask the Bush government hard questions and lets them get away with way too much. it doesn't seem too illegitimate to say "well let's be sure who just punched us before we pull out our bazoka." 2) since late 2002, A TON OF NEW INFORMATION HAS COME OUT CONFIRMING BIN LADEN'S ROLE IN 9/11. 3) there is no indication that Iraq had anything to do with 9/11, or terrorists at all, so if the war on Iraq is diverting troops and resources from fighting Al Qaida, then it should be viewed as a distraction from the real danger facing america. what's so wrong with that. Hitchen next brushes over a bunch of points in the movie, in something resembling the argumentation, in the way that a peapod might resemble the virgin mary: Fahrenheit 9/11 makes the following points about Bin Laden and about Afghanistan, and makes them in this order: 1) The Bin Laden family (if not exactly Osama himself) had a close if convoluted business relationship with the Bush family, through the Carlyle Group. 2) Saudi capital in general is a very large element of foreign investment in the United States. 3) The Unocal company in Texas had been willing to discuss a gas pipeline across Afghanistan with the Taliban, as had other vested interests. 4) The Bush administration sent far too few ground troops to Afghanistan and thus allowed far too many Taliban and al-Qaida members to escape. 5) The Afghan government, in supporting the coalition in Iraq, was purely risible in that its non-army was purely American. 6) The American lives lost in Afghanistan have been wasted. (This I divine from the fact that this supposedly "antiwar" film is dedicated ruefully to all those killed there, as well as in Iraq.) It must be evident to anyone, despite the rapid-fire way in which Moore's direction eases the audience hastily past the contradictions, that these discrepant scatter shots do not cohere at any point. you're right, they don't cohere into one point. they cohere into many. 1,2, and 3 show an alternate agenda the bush family might have for forcing a culture war in Iraq. I think Moore showed how the Carlyle group, Bush's family, et.al made a ton of money off of government weapons contracts and it certainly does call into question Bush's credibility if not his motives. 4) I hate this argument more than I hate root canals. Clearly, someone might argue on TWO different levels, saying "we shouldn't be in Iraq in the first place. but since we apparently are going in anyway, we should do it right, and send in enough troops to be effective." 5) not really an argument at all, but more like a bit of sarcastic witticism. but also points out how flimsy the coalition of the willing actually is beyond the US and Britian. 6) Hitchens is a complete shithead. (this i divine from the fact that his sixth argument is a total load of crap that deserves neither time nor argument. you should be able to see why it should be dismissed on face.) but if you are obtuse enough to think that its a good argument, here's the counter: Moore also didn't dedicate his movie to cancer patients, does that mean he's for cancer? Hitchen then tries to put together some conflicting arguments. . . well, first i'd say that Moore often uses conflicting arguments to illustrate different aspects of the same point. but let that go, because i don't think Hitchens point out any. more to come. wait, before i go home for the day, I want to point out the worst false dichotomy i have ever seen: Bush is shown frozen on his chair at the infant school in Florida, looking stunned and useless for seven whole minutes after the news of the second plane on 9/11. Many are those who say that he should have leaped from his stool, adopted a Russell Crowe stance, and gone to work. I could even wish that myself. But if he had done any such thing then (as he did with his "Let's roll" and "dead or alive" remarks a month later), half the Michael Moore community would now be calling him a man who went to war on a hectic, crazed impulse. indeed we would, because, as president, Bush should NEITHER sit back for seven minutes doing nothing while our country is under attack-- especially given recent findings that show how inept our response was-- NOR should he haphazardly go to war, randomly attacking a country which has nothing to do with the war on terror, but will make Bush's family a hell of a lot of money.

That title is a bit of a lie. If someone put a gun to my head and forced me to pick one of the two major parties (perhaps the wierdest mugging ever!) I'd probably say "democrat," and count my self a conservative democrat. Still, while my feet are nailed (that sounds too messianic, let's say 'Planted,' instead) firmly in the middle, my head-- and heart-- often pulls me slightly to one side or the other from time to time. (to the left on social issues, and to the right on fiscal matters) The problem, as I see it, is adherance to politics as a dogma: too many people have adopted "the welfare state," or "smaller government" as an Ideology, rather than a pragmatic solution to a societal ill. I would say that we all have certain goals for what society should be, and, i would guess that, despite some minor differences, they would all resemble the same thing. (my libertarian friends-- most notably Julian and Amy (further sidenote: Julian, that your blogs--www.juliansanches.com AND r:h&r-- don't appear on my roll to the side is a terrible oversight, to be corrected soon enough) and my Hippy friends, most notably Storey and--slightly less so--Emily MIGHT be the exceptions to that rule. But libertarians and hippies have always been slightly off the left-center-right axis) Take, for example, the idea of a social safety net. I think that even the most staunch republican and the most bleeding heart liberal would agree that its good for society to not have people starving on the streets, homeless despite a job, etc. and, indeed, that is a goal, perhaps one of the most important goals, of a just goverment: social order. Where the left and right differ is how to acheive that goal. each side would propose a different way to get to that goal: a giant subsidized housing program, perhaps; or for the right, a decentralized, state-by-state approach, maybe even organized through a church or two. Obviously i've pigeonholed both sides here, but i'm trying to make a point, not a policy. The problem comes when we stop thinking of those remedies as remedies and start thinking of them as the goal, themselves. We don't, and shouldn't, want government programs (or lack thereof) for themselves, but rather, because they acheive (or don't) a particular societal goal. To that end, I'll never preach "big government spending," or "tax-and-spend" or "supply-side economics" or "more local control" of any policy as the good, in and of itself. If you can show me a huge government program that both runs smoothly, with little waste, and provides for the common good, I'll probably support it. But, say, then, a more conservative policy wonk shows up and provides me with a better, more efficent, decentralized approach, i'd probably swich my vote. and then when the liberal comes back with a better still system, i'd flip-flop back again. the point isn't to adhere to policy no matter the cost.
